Chapleau May 25th, 1932.

Sir,

I herewith beg leaves to enclose list of necessary expenditures to be made at the Chapleau Indian school for this year so that the buildings, fences and premises may be kept up to the standard of repair.

In connection with the fire escapes these fire escapes only reach to the main floor and it is twelve feet from there to the ground with no avenue of escape except the stairs leading down; and were there to be a fire on the lower floor and the place filled with smoke there might possibly be accidents in getting the children out in case of fire.

I would strongly recommend that some provision be made to remedy this condition.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 30, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from the Principal of the Chapleau Indian Residential School containing a list of materials required for repairs to buildings, fences, etc.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase from firms on the list to receive consideration of the following: 500 feet dressed inch lumber for general repairs; 5 gallons inside white paint; 5 gallons outside white paint; 3 gallons outside light grey paint; 4 paint brushes; 10 bags Portland cement; 50 rods hog tight wire fencing; 100 feet galvanized wire; 30 pounds bicarbonate of soda and 1/2 gallon sulphuric acid for fire extinguishers. After the above purchases have been made, you should forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Regarding the 12 refills for Pyrene Fire Extinguishers, I have to say that you have not stated the size or type, and we are unable to place the order here. You may place an order with the Pyrene Mfg. Co. of Canada Limited, 1197-1207 King St. W., Toronto 2, Ont., to supply the refills that would be suitable for the type of Pyrene extinguishers for which they are required. When same are received, you should instruct the Principal to see that they are installed in the extinguishers. The account, in triplicate, should be forwarded, properly certified, covering the cost.

Regarding an extension to the two ladder fire escapes, I have to request that, after consulting the Principal, you will forward a recommendation stating what you would advise be done in making an extension to the fire escapes, in order that they will be more usable and provide proper means of egress from the building in case of fire. A statement of the cost should be given. I may add that the Department is not prepared, owing to the cost involved, to install escapes of the spiral chute type. When you have full information regarding the extension required to the present fire escapes and the cost involved consideration will then be given to authorizing having the work carried out. I shall be pleased to have your early reply.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

T. J. Godfrey, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chapleau, Ont.

Ottawa, July 20, 1938.

Sir,

I instructed the Chapleau Agency on the 29th ultimo and beg to submit the following report:

I visited the Chapleau Indian Residential School and found everything very satisfactory. The buildings and equipment are in excellent condition. The interior of the school is kept tidy, sanitary and spotlessly clean. The pupils remaining in residence during holidays looked real well, healthy and happy. Six pupils passed entrance this term. Dr. Sheahan reports the health of the school very good.

The new fire escapes are a great improvement. Fire drill is regularly carried out. Some of the smaller pupils get frightened descending the steps. The backs of the steps are open and look dangerous to them. I would recommend that Agent Godfrey be authorized to purchase sufficient wire netting to cover the back part of the steps. The cost would be very small and it would add to the protection of the pupils.

The barn has not yet been completed to provide a hay mow and the management is handicapped in having to buy hay in small quantities. I reported upon this last year but lack of funds prevented the work being done. If funds are available it should be done this fall.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector.
Sir:

Mr. Inspector MacGookin, who recently visited the Chapleau Indian Residential School, drew attention to the new fire escapes. He recommends that wire netting be installed at the back of the steps, which are open. He states that the younger pupils are frightened descending the steps. It is considered that, with small expense, wire netting could be installed at the back of the steps, and I have to request that you will arrange with the Principal to have this done as soon as possible. Any expenditure in connection with this work will be paid upon receipt of a voucher, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

T. J. Godfrey, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Chapleau, Ont.

REV. A. J. VALE—Principal

P.J. GODFREY M.A.Q.,
INDIAN AGENT,
CHAPLEAU ONTARIO,

Dear Mr Godfrey:-

With further reference to our conversation in connection with the advisability of removing the rainstreaking from the school, I beg to report it is in very bad condition in some places and we should either have it repaired or all removed for as it is it is a menace. Much water runs from the leaks and breaks and forms large icicles in the winter of great weight and size. In addition, now in the summer, it runs down and spoils the walls. I write to see if the Department would agree to pay for a man to remove it. It is too high for the school boys to attempt alone. They could help so that one man only would be required to do the work.

I shall be very glad if you will consult the Department on this matter as I would like it done before I go on my holidays next month.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Chapleau Augst 14th, 1932.

Sir,

I hereby leave to enclose a communication received from the Rev. Principal of the Chapleau Residential school relative to the cavelostroughing on the main building of the Chapleau Indian school.

I have gone into this matter with the Principal and he as well as myself believe that it would be better if the troughing were removed altogether instead of having it repaired. From personal experience of over thirty-five years in this cold climate I have found that cavestroughing is not a success as the ice forms on them and then backs the water up on the roof causing the roof to leak during the day when the sun is warm enough to melt the ice, and in addition to this it forms ice in the trough and overflows down the side of the building freezing and thawing and causing the stucco to loosen and fall off.

The cost of repairs would be considerable as the troughs are damaged in many places and would be hard to repair, and the removal of them would cost very little as with the help of a plumber for one day and the assistance of some of the larger boys of the school the old troughs could be removed, and by their removal I believe much of the leaks would be stopped.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Chapleau Indian Residential School in which it is recommended that the eaves troughing on the main building be entirely removed instead of having it repaired.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of having the eaves troughing removed, provided you consider that the drip from the roof would not injure the foundation of the building. The plumber engaged should be on the list to receive consideration. Any expenses will be paid upon receipt from you of a voucher, in triplicate, properly certified.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your request for recommendations as to how our Fire Escapes could be made more efficient, I would say I have carefully studied the matter. As they are now placed, they are by means of them in from the attic or third floor, where we have no children at all, other than four senior boys who attend the High School, thence to the second floor by an exposed pole to slide down to indoors of the Ground or main floor of the building inside and no connecting escape from there to the ground about twelve feet above the surface of the ground for we have a basement under what I have termed the ground floor, perhaps better designated as the main floor of the building.

My suggestion would be to drop these existing escapes to a position suitable for access from the second floor which is used for dormitories. By so doing with very little if any additional steps, would provide direct access from the Dormitories. This would entail services of competent labor to detach and attach the escapes in the new positions. The existing escapes would be utilized with the added protection of being wired in on the side and underneath so as to give the children confidence in using them. I feel we would then with small expense have an efficient Fire Escape and would feel great relief in the knowledge we have done our part to make them safe.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Chapleau Augst 27th, 1932.

Sir,

I herewith beg leave to refer again to the matter of the Fire Escapes at the Chapleau Indian School, which in their present situation are practically useless, and I have gone into the matter thoroughly with the Rev. Principal and he thinks it me that to lower the escape one story bringing the entrance to them from the rain dormitories and thence to the ground adequate escapes would then be provided, and in addition to lowering the escape place the heavy netting placed on them to protect the smaller children.

I have not gone into the cost of the change but from personal knowledge of the work entailed it would not amount to much as but one skilled mechanic would be required and assisted by the larger boys this work could be done at a minimum of cost, and would supply adequate protection to all the children sleeping in the dormitories.

If the Department would consider this change which both the Rev. Principal and myself strongly recommend I could if necessary secure a price on the change but the lowering them down would not entail much cost.

Mr. McGookin, of the Department looked over these escapes and could explain just their position or by looking up the blue prints of this school you would see how useless these escapes are at present in their present situation.

I am enclosing the Rev' Principals letter to me written after we had looked the matter over.

Waiting your instructions in the matter I beg to remain.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, September 1st, 1932.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Chapleau Indian Residential School relative to the fire escapes.

In reply I have to request that you will furnish an estimate of the cost of carrying out the recommendation of the Principal, viz., that the existing fire escapes be lowered to a position suitable for access from the second floor, which is used for dormitories. It is noted that this would entail the services of a skilled mechanic to attach the escapes from their present position and lower them in the new position. I would request that you secure a price on making the change, together with an estimate of the cost of having the escapes wired on the side and underneath, and forward same for the consideration of the Department. Please give this matter your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Chapleau August 31st, 1932.

Sir,

I beg leave to acknowledge official letter #65-1-5 of August 24th, relative to my mistake in ordering the refills for the fire extinguishers for the Chapleau Indian school, and I can only explain the matter by acknowledging my oversight in ordering them as there were so many articles mentioned in the letter I failed to remember that it had mentioned in the letter that they were to be purchased from the firm at Toronto, and as I was placing the order for the other material at Messrs Smith & Chapple I also ordered this material from them at the same time.

I am very sorry for my mistake, and if you will give me the price that they could have been secured at from the manufacturer I am quite sure if I were to take the matter up with Messrs Smith and Chapple that they would meet their prices plus the freight or possibly within a small percentage of their price.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Indian Agent.
Dear Inspector McGookin:

I am about to go off on a month's vacation.

I had hoped it would be possible to have arranged to have the light at our gateway installed before I left. Have you had a chance to bring the matter before the Department Head? I also desire to report once again we were unable to store all our grain in the barn. It would perhaps be a good time to get the roof raised now, when wages are low and so many men needing work.

I understand things may be a little out of gear in the office for a time succeeding the sudden death of Mr Ferrier.

With kindest regards I am yours sincerely

Principal.
Ottawa, September 3rd, 1932.

Reverend Sir,

Mr. Inspector McGookin has drawn attention to your letter to him of the 31st ultimo, regarding the installing of a light at the gateway at the Chapleau Indian Residential School. In this connection, I would request that you forward, through the office of Mr. Agent Godfrey, an estimate of the cost of the wiring and fixtures required in the installation of the light. When this is received, consideration will be given as to whether the expenditure for the purpose can be provided or not.

I may add that it would not be possible for the Department to pay the fees charged by the Electric Light Co. for the operation of the light.

Regarding the raising of the roof of the barn, I have to say that we will not have funds this year to provide the expenditure required for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Your letter dated 16th instant, for some unaccountable reason, reached me this morning.

From what I know of the matter, the account is an old one and was brought up in the last days, so nothing was accomplished and the bill at Polyeye.

Although you be not so clever, believe the account is a fine one. Yours, however, probably is demanded for some such literature.

I imagine the whole matter with your "editorial" speech, and perhaps something like three years ago and if my memory serves me right, then about a little over thirty dollars.

And from this point of the conversation at Polyeye, a young woman spoke up and said she had heard of the matter and took it upon herself to investigate the matter and take up the affair. Having no money, having no opportunity, paid nothing.

Out of my own pocket and explained to the officers that I had found the situation in which things financially put in a class of denominations and I have never hesitated to say that there is not any way.

Then we took over the work there, there was a nice little Sunday School with 17 pupils on the roll and two teachers. Within a very short time the whole school broke up and I understand that the literature continued to circulate and that they were kind of let out of the minute matter to the United Church School.

About the same thing happened at St. Mary's Church. The Sunday School there went all to pieces. At both places we have reorganized with a membership of about 22 at Polyeye and about 18 at Rogers. In each case however, we are hardly able to take care of our current expenses.

The congregations though not slackening in numbers have been hit so hard through the closing down of lumbering operations and the laying off of men formerly employed on the railway, and in such shape financially that they are unable to take care of the insurance on the buildings, and that the finances do not bear current expenses. The situation is one of extreme urgency, there being so much to do in order that every center is ministered to our utmost ability as should be seen by our aid, and rather than the work should be hampered through lack of means, I am carrying on at considerable cost to myself.

I am now very excited about the possibility of the church being able to continue its usefulness, but he must take charge by his own means that the church is kept in good repair and his requirements will be met by a worthy man on the part of any minister who has been faithful even as he goes along in a broken ministry.

You will be able to gather from the above that there is only little possibility of this account ever doing more than spoken in the interest of the congregation on the matter and the cause of God. It is not likely that I am willing to do anything myself.

Dear Sir:

I have to report a peculiar accident happened on Monday the 13th when we were using the power saw. It gradually slowed down and the engines turned on the carburettor a bit to give a little extra gas. We kept it going more quickly when suddenly it blew the cylinder part of the engine right off the frame. It broke the iron casting of the engine bed and ripped off the bolts holding it to the portable frame.

On examining the engine I find the following parts have been broken and will have to be replaced:

1. Engine Bed casting, 2 D.A. 125.
2. Magneto trip T. 37
3. D.A. Guard, 162.
4. Trip Rod Guard, 223.
5. Exhaust valve Spring large one.
6. Oilier Glass

Unfortunately I cannot give the name or maker of this engine. I only know it was bought of the T.Eaton Co., Toronto through you and the Department of Indian Affairs Ottawa, I think about three years ago.

I can assure you there was no neglect or rough handling of the machine. It was purely an accident while in operation.

I hope this may receive immediate attention as we seriously need the machine to cut our wood for the school use.

Yours very sincerely,

Sir,

I beg leave to report that acting on your authority given in official letter #65-1-55 of July 14th, I had the water supply pipe at the school dug up and had it cut and examined and when inspecting the whole system I found it in a very bad state as there is no way of cleaning the pipe other than by opening it and reversing the pressure from the fire pump driving the water and refuse back against the gravity pressure. First we tried to clean it by doing this but it would not work as the refuse in the pipe would not go back through the screen then we cut the pipe and blew it out through the opening and the filth composed of old leaves, grass, rotten wood and such like was very bad and we were very lucky that there was not an epidemic of sickness at the school from this water supply. Sir,

In connection with Official letter #65-1-5, of Sept 8th, I beg leave to report that I have taken the matter up with the Chapleau Electric Light & Power Co and they object to having their Dam interfered with as the water main passes through the Core Wall or rather beneath the wall and they are afraid that were we to dig beneath the wall that the dam would be greatly damaged & as the Dam is situated on top of a hill I can also see the danger of interfering with it.

I have drawn a rough sketch showing the Dam and also the water main to the school and you will readily see that it is impossible to install a new line without first lowering the water level some eight or ten feet and this the Power Co. will not do at this time of year as their reserve is very small and they are afraid of shortage of water, and the only other solution would be to have a Diver go down remove the old screen then place a longer piece of pipe where the line is marked in Red and then cleaning the old screen or replacing it with a new screen.

This work would have to be done by the Diver and the principal cost would be his railway fare To and from Ottawa, and the time he was at work as he would not require an assistant as I am personally familiar with Diver Tenders work and could attend him while down as I have had experience with this work owing to my Brother having been a Diver and having worked for him while diving.

I have thought out every possible way of setting this repair aside but owing to the dam & its situation we can work out no other plan except the work to be done by a Diver.

In cleaning out the pipe it has increased the flow sufficient for domestic purposes but not for fire purposes if the fire hose has to be used as the pump drains the water faster than the supply and creates a vacuum thus there is no pressure but if you think fit it can lay over for another year.

October 19, 1953.

Dear Mr. Phillips,

With further reference to my memorandum of the 10th ultimo, turned out hereunder, I beg to advise that Indian Agent Godfrey has written the Department, stating that he was unable to secure the services of a diver from Ballyacy, so there is none in the locality, in order to carry out the repairs authorized to the inside of the water supply system at the Shilo Indian Residential School, for which work Mr. L. J. and Sons have been authorized an amount of $100.00.

As it is important that this work be proceeded with as early as possible, I beg to request, as recommended by the Indian Agent, that a diver who has had experience in this kind of work, be sent from here, with the necessary equipment which can be rented as is usually done.

I personally know a plumber, Mr. Alwyn Leblanc of Bell, who has had many years of experience as a diver, and who is willing to undertake the work at a very reasonable charge, providing he is given all the necessary assistance on the site of the work, which, according to the Indian Agent, would be forthcoming. Mr. Leblanc has done similar work in Pembroke, Bancroft and other places with entire satisfaction, and would be prepared to proceed to Chapleau at a few days' notice. He would be willing to do the work for $10.00 per day plus travelling and living expenses and would look after the renting of the diving apparatus, the renting of which would cost around $2.00 per day from the time it leaves the storeroom to the day of its return.

I estimate that the work could be performed within a week's time, and that the cost would not exceed the amount authorized.

Would you please advise if the employment of Mr. Leblanc would be satisfactory to you, if not give me the name of another diver with the required experience to whom the work could be entrusted.

Dear Mr Godfrey:

With further reference to our conversation of the other day I beg to ask you if you will try to secure from the Department of Indian Affairs three FIFTY foot lengths of fire hose size one and one half inches and a Nozzle of three eights size to fit same so that we may have a fair chance to fight fire in an emergency which we hope will never come to our lot but would like to feel we are prepared in the case of need. You will recall we have one length attached now to each Hydrant but that is so short it would not give us a chance to fight from the outside of the building in case of need.

I shall feel very much more safe if I have this apparatus on hand. I think then we can make a real effort in case of need until the Town apparatus can reach us.

I wish to thank you and through you the Department for sending up the Diver to put our intake pipe in good shape.

I am yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Sir,

I beg leave to enclose letter received from the Rev. Principal of the Chapleau Indian Residential School and which will explain the situation relative to the Fire hose question.

At present there is not sufficient hose to reach outside the building unless taken from the different outlets, and should an emergency arise this would be dangerous, and I would recommend that three more lengths of hose be supplied of fifty feet each, and another nozzle of 3/8" size so that water could be thrown on top of the building as the nozzles in use are too large an outlet to force the water to the top of the building.

We were able with the assistance of the Diver Mr. Leblanc to put the water main in such shape that it should never again give any such trouble as it can be lifted now and the intake screen or foot valve cleaned without the necessity of a Diver.

Mr. Leblanc found the foot valve more than half buried in the sand on the bottom from not being properly installed but now we have the foot valve about four feet off the bottom and in such shape to allow it to be raised and lowered when necessary.

Mr. Leblanc recommended that an air chamber or short length of pipe be placed on the intake close to the pump to allow any air that may accumulate be drawn off as the style of pump used does not work successfully if air reaches it and I am having this done immediately, and will forward all accounts for settlement immediately the work is completed.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

I beg leave to report that the water main supplying water to the Chapleau Indian school by gravity burst some time Saturday night leaving the school without water supply, and as there was no way of getting water other than by hauling by teams and barrels I had the service dug up and repaired as quickly as possible working under very difficult conditions but managed to get the service working again.

It was necessary to secure the services of a plumber as well as securing some new pipes and fixtures, and the labor was supplied by the school.

We could not ascertain what caused the pipes to separate other than that a small leak started and this caused a wash-out under the piping and the weight over the pipe caused them to sag and separate but I am glad to report that it is again in good working order.

I would, therefore, again earnestly commend this suggestion to your careful and sympathetic consideration, as I feel confident the school work at many of the schools, such as the one at Chapleau, and the others I have mentioned, cannot be carried on to the best advantage until the additional facilities for vocational training, class-room, and recreational purposes, have been provided.

The Principal of our Chapleau School has informed me that this school was visited by the Public School Inspector on the 6th inst., and that in his report to your Department, he is again directing attention to the need of an additional class-room, and an additional room for recreation purposes. As the need of these improvements, is, I believe, fully understood by your Department, I sincerely trust some effort may be made to provide them during the coming summer.

As this is not the only school which stands in need of the very same improvements, may I commend to your careful and sympathetic consideration, the recommendation by our Commission and submitted annually with their list of requirements for the Elkhorn, Onion Lake, Lac la Ronge and other schools, that the additional space required be provided through the erection of a building quite separate from the main school building, with class-room facilities in the upper story, and facilities for vocational training in the basement underneath. The class-room could be separated by folding doors which, when opened, would convert all the class-room space into an assembly room. Facilities for vocational training are essential in our system of Indian education is to fit the pupils for the place they will be expected to take in the modern world, and these facilities can be provided at a minimum of cost in the way suggested. The removal of the class-room to a detached building, would leave space in the main school building for the additional recreational purposes required, and it would also, I venture to think, be a great help in maintaining the health of both staff and pupils.

Sir,

I herewith beg leave to submit to the Department requisition for necessary repairs and some new work at the Chapleau Indian school.

First there is the matter of the raising of the roof of the barn and estimate of $240.00 has been given but going into this very carefully and taking into consideration the increased cost of material since this estimate was given I feel an additional 20% should be added to this cost.

Second there is the matter of the necessary painting of all the buildings inside and out which should be done this year, the work to be done by the school staff, and boys.

Third there is the matter of a suitable drain from the Boiler room this was never installed and as the boilers have to be washed out often there is absolutely no way to get rid of the water other than by letting it soak away in the ground through the cement and this is very detrimental to the foundation of the building as well as very unhealthy. I went into this fully with the Inspector Mr. McEachin on his last trip here and he agreed with me that this should be attended too, and we thought possibly we might be able to do it last year with our allowance for repairs but were unable to do so.

There is also the matter of repairs to the cooking ranges, also the Bake ovens are also in very bad repair through constant use.

There is also the matter of one dozen Mattresses which should be renewed as the old ones are becoming very badly worn.

I am enclosing for your information the Rev. Principals letters to me which gives fully all requirements which were fully gone into by the Principal and myself before submitting, and I am enclosing tenders on all material required.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

It is proposed to carry out certain repairs and painting at the Indian Residential School at Chapleau, Ont. (Federal District of Algoma West). The work to be performed is as follows:

Sir,

I beg leave to report that the water main of the supply line furnishing water to the Indian school has again broken and cut off the water supply for several hours.

Immediately this was reported to me I secured the services of a plumber and had the pipe repaired so that water could be secured for the school.

This is the third time that this water main has given way this winter, and which is very bad as there is no other source of supply, and as the frost has not gone out of the ground here not very much could be done to locate the exact trouble but as soon as weather permits this work should be attended to and the source of the trouble learned.

So far as I can learn at present there seems to be small leaks forming in the pipe line and the line being laid along the side of a hill and the washed out portion of the earth causes pressure on the pipe and it becomes disconnected other than this we can not ascertain what is just the trouble but I believe the line along this exposed portion should be dug up and proper bracing inserted to prevent another break.

Sir,

Replying to official letter #65-1-5, of May 13th, I beg leave to report that I have gone into the matter fully with an Engineer living at Chapleau, and after going into the matter fully he believes that the trouble with the present system is that there is a blockage in the pipes and that if they could be blown out that there is plenty of water to supply all wants of the school providing the pipes can be kept clear but with the distance of 1025 feet the distance from intake to storage tank with only a three inch main the friction is considerable and if the pipes are not kept clear of silt that the supply is greatly decreased.

He proposed that I secure the services of the Town Fire pumping engine and put pressure on the main and by so doing he believes that the main can be cleared but this cannot be done until I have the drain installed from the boiler room, and as soon as I have this work completed I will try this suggestion and if this method works it will save digging up the entire main or disturbing the system.

The Power Co., who own the Dam where the water main goes through the wall will not consent to installing a larger intake main, and unless we can clear the present main I am at a loss to know what to suggest but will try out the clearing the present system if possible.

As soon as I have tried this method I will report to Department the results.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

With further reference to Official letter of May 15th, #65-1-8, and my letter to Department in answer to date May 31st I beg leave to report that the Drain Pipe has been installed and is entirely satisfactory, and that while Mr. McCookin, of the Department was here on his official visit that I secured the services of the Town Fire Pumper and had the water main flushed out clearing considerable sediment and refuse that had accumulated during the years that the water main has been in use.

Also while doing this work Fire drill was put on and the Fire pump was also used and worked satisfactorily which it would not do before the main was cleaned out as it could not supply sufficient water and the pump when used at full capacity to unable them to throw the water over the building the shortage of water caused a vacuum and would stop the flow of water, and I am glad to report that this trouble has been eliminated, and it is my intention to have the main blown out at least once or twice a year providing I can secure the services of the Town Fire Engine and pump, and I feel quite sure this can be done as the Firemen have a yearly practice at the school once a year and have agreed to do this work once a year while at their annual practise at the school.

I do not anticipate any trouble with the main and do not think at the present time it will be necessary to make any changes to the Water Main but I would like to recommend that should at any time the Electric Power Company decide to drain the Dam that a larger intake be installed above and through the dam with a shut-off valve on the School side of the Dam using at least a six inch main through the dam.

As the water main is at present the shut-off valve is above the Dam and out of commission and cannot be reached as it is some twenty feet out in the water above the dam and to shut off the water it is necessary to raise the water main out of the water an arrangement I had installed The Secretary while having the use of the Diver to repair the pipe and Department of install a new foot valve, this is not so satisfactory Indian Affairs but answers the present needs until such time as the Ottawa, Ont. dam is drained and we can replace the pipe and Valve.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent
I beg leave to report that the brick arches in the Fire Box of the Boilers at the Chapleau Indian school are in very bad state of repair caused by burning wood during the past winter and will have to be repaired before putting in use in the fall and going into the matter with the Town Engineer he advised me that instead of repairing them with Fire Brick which has been the habit the past number of years that a more permanent job can be done with a new material that is out called Plastic Fire Brick & which he claims has given excellent satisfaction and far more lasting than the old method of renewing with fire brick.

I have examined the arches and it would take about 600 lbs. of this plastic brick at a cost of six & half cts. per lb. along with the old arches to make a good job of the arches and the help at the school could do all the work.

Will you please advise me if I may go ahead and order this material and have the work done immediately as the nights are getting cold here in the North and fire has to be lighted occasionally.

Waiting your instructions I beg to remain;

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

The Estimates which you submitted last fall included the following items for the Chapleau Indian Residential School:

- Repairs to electrical equipment, meters, pumping and heating plant.
- Painting of buildings and other general repairs.
- New installation in barn.

I have to inform you that provision has been made in the Appropriation for the current fiscal year to carry out the work absolutely necessary as mentioned above.

I would request that you consult the Principal and communicate with the Department, stating in detail the repairs required to the electrical equipment, the cost of the new installation in the barn, any repairs necessary to the building and also any painting to the interior of the school. You should state, also, what outside labour would be required. The Department requests that you give as complete information as possible regarding the work that the Principal and yourself consider necessary during the coming summer.

I may add that there will be no funds to cover the cost of any painting to the exterior of the building.

When we have the information asked for above, consideration will be given as to the work that can be authorized, and you will be advised regarding the purchase of material and the labour.

I beg to submit the following report on my inspection of the Chapleau Agency on the 29th-30th ultimo.

The Chapleau Residential School was visited, everything found satisfactory. The buildings and equipment are in good condition. The interior of the School is well ventilated, tidy and spotlessly clean. The pupils remaining in school for the holidays look happy, neat, and well cared for. Dr. Sheehan reports the health condition in the School very good.

The recently finished barn is a great improvement to the appearance of the School property, and provides much needed accommodation for feed, etc.

The stucco on the front walls of the School has cracked badly, the severe winter frosts are damaging a larger area each year. It would be well spent money to have repairs made before the winter sets in. A cement wash has been suggested at a cost of $475.00 for a guaranteed job.

I beg leave to report that the water main at the Chapleau Indian school has again given away and at present the school is without water except what they have with barrels, and I have men working on the main trying to get the pipe line repaired as quickly as possible.

I am unable to ascertain why this line breaks as this is the third time it has given way. I have had men examine the line to try to secure information as to why this line gives away. No one seems to be able to explain why it breaks. It is the tremendous pressure on top of the pipe line forcing the pipe down until the joints give away as there is considerable weight of sand over the pipe & the pipe being laid along the side of a hill it apparently seems to slip then the joints give away.

I propose building bents under the bad section then filling in with cinders so that there will be less weight on the line; I can secure cinders from the Railway at no cost only the hauling which can be done by truck, and I believe this will overcome the trouble if not I am at a loss to know what to do.

I will have the repairs carried out at little cost as possible but an experienced man will be required to repair the pipe the other work can be done at by the older boys at the school except the cost of the truck.

Your obedient servant,

I have leave to report that the Globe wood washer was ordered for use at the Chapleau Indian school, and that with the make of washer sent it has not the proper fixtures on it to attach the pulley frame work belonging to the washer.

It appears they have sent the washer illustrated on page 3 showing the attachments necessary to attach the pulley frame work necessary to operate the washer, what they should have sent was the washer illustrated on page 3, showing the attachments necessary to operate the machine.

From examination of the machine sent it appears that the frame work might be attached on the right end but no provision has been made to attach the frame on the left hand end of the machine, and there is no way of having this altered here unless the Company would send up one of their machines.

The illustration on page 3 is a duplicate of the machine which is not fit for operation with the exception that there is an extension shaft to carry the pulley for the dryer used at the school as roughly sketched on the page 3.

The castings on the right side appear to be the proper one to attach the pulley frame too but the casting on the left side no provision is made to attach the frame work of the pulley attachment, but possibly if a man were sent from the factory he might be able to disassemble the new machine and make use of the castings of the old machine and be able to assemble the new machine with the old frame work attached making it workable, but there is no man available here.

I would care to recommend to attempt this work, and really think a man will have to be sent from the factory to install the machine, and even at that I feel that a new casting for the left side suitable for attaching the pulley frame will have to be installed before the machine can be operated successfully.

Waiting your instructions I beg to remain.

The inner cylinder shall be 36 inches in diameter by 6 feet 4 inches in length and shall have one door and no partitions. Hinges, catches and hoops shall be single geared.

Tub
Shall be constructed of Clear and Better Fir, with staves cut from 2-inch stock. Staves shall be tongued and grooved and gained to fit over heads cut from 2-inch stock, to which they shall be nailed.

A galvanized-iron sliding door shall operate in grooves provided on adjustable encircling bands or hoops. Brass spran shall be fitted at bottom of door opening to protect staves.

Iron Frames
The entire weight of cylinder and tub shall rest on cast-iron frames of neat design, to which the driving mechanism shall be attached. Frames shall be bolted to tub heads, shall be solid one-piece castings, having upright extension and shall hold driving mechanism and provide bearings at each end of driving shafts.

The through the hole shall act as a stiffness to the upright extensions of frames.

Dear Sir:

I have to inform you the flange on the water intake pipe in the dam that supplies water for the school is broken off completely.

When lifting the pipe for the Fire Brigade to clean the pipe, the Tripod that kept the pipe off the bottom got misplaced by coming apart at the place where it was joined.

The boys dove down into the water the other day and got it up so we repaired it and today tried to put it back. We had left a rope tied to the pipe to make it easy to get up again. When we raised the pipe today we found it was completely off. I told the men to pull it ashore to see what the trouble was and found as reported above the flange had broken off. There were only two bolts in the flange and the break took place in each case just at the bolts.

I am sending the broken flange in so you can get another to replace it. I fear we cannot make the repair under the water. I suppose it will mean getting the DIVER again. In the meantime we shall have to go on using the water without a sleeve covering over the end of the pipe and take a chance on not getting dirt in it.

I shall be glad to have your advice in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.
Sir,

I beg leave to report that the intake pipe which supplies water to the Chapleau Indian Residential School has broken apart, and that it will be necessary to have Diver and equipment to make the connection where being about ten feet of water over this intake pipe.

There was difficulty with this intake pipe in 1933 it became blocked allowing very little water to be secured through the pipe and on October 26th, 1933 the Department sent Diver Leblanc from Ottawa to make repairs and the repairs have been satisfactory since that time until July 26th when having the Chapleau Fire Engine & Fire Department blow out the Intake pipe which they kindly do once a year & when raising the pipe to clean the foot valve the pipe came disconnected displacing the Tripod which holds the Pipe off the bed of the river, and now the pipe is lying on the bottom with no screening or foot valve on the open pipe to prevent sediment or dirt blocking the pipe and the situation is very dangerous as there is a great quantity of refuse floating in the river where the intake lies.

Ottawa is the only place I believe that Diver and his equipment can be secured at the present time as there is no Divers located near this District.

It will be necessary to have him bring a 3" Flange Coupling and a 3" Elbo to make the connection anything else necessary to make the repairs can be purchased locally.

The repairs are very urgent as blocking of the pipe would be serious as it would be hard to clear as there is over 1000 feet of pipe from River to the School.

I am enclosing the Rev. Principals letter to me and I have looked over the situation and find it impossible to make the repairs without assistance of Diver & Equipment.

The Secretary, Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Mills,

Referring to your letter of the 5th ultimo, addressed to Mr. A. LeBlanc, Plumbing Contractor of Hull, authorizing certain repairs to the water supply system at the Indian Residential School at Chapleau, Ontario, I beg to report as follows:

The repairs carried out consisted mainly in the replacing of the three inch flanged union at the intake pipe, which was located at a depth of ten feet in the lake - which had been broken. The work was performed as speedily as possible with the assistance of Mr. Godfrey, the Indian Agent, and the Engineer in charge of the heating, plumbing and water supply system at the school.

The diving apparatus used was borrowed by us from the Federal Department of Public Works here and shipped to Chapleau and back by freight. It was returned to the storehouse by Mr. LeBlanc in the same condition as when taken away.

The whole water supply system of the School was carefully tested and left in a good working order before Mr. LeBlanc went away. The cost of the aforementioned inspection and repairs performed by Mr. LeBlanc may be given as follows:

| Description                          | Cost   |
|--------------------------------------|--------|
| Wages to LeBlanc                    | $63.75 |
| Materials, fittings, etc.            | $8.00  |
| Travelling and other miscellaneous expenses as per accompanying detailed statement | $21.15 |

$152.90

I might say that there will be, in addition to the above, a few small accounts to come for expenditures incurred by Indian Agent Godfrey in connection with this work. I presume that they will be paid directly by the Indian Affairs Branch, where they will be sent.

As Mr. LeBlanc arrived at Chapleau before delivery of the diving equipment, tools, etc., the Rev. Principal Canoe Yale took advantage of his visit to have him make an inspection of the steam heating and plumbing system at the School which were defective or in need of improvement.

S. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Service
Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa
It had been suggested at first that a number of Dunham Valves be entirely replaced, but it was found upon this inspection that only the coverings and discs of some fifteen valves would have to be replaced, as well as some of the packless radiator valves.

The pumping machinery was also inspected, and it was found that some repairs will have to be made to the electrical motor operating the system, by an expert electrician.

Mr. Laflamme, upon request from the Rev. Principal, gave some valuable advice as to some additional plumbing service which is necessary to the School, giving a list of materials required, etc.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

May I ask if the contract for the necessary repairs to our school, which I understand was being sanctioned, has been forwarded? My reason for this is the fact that I recall your saying they ought to be made early. I happen to know this would be a convenient time for the contractor as he has just finished another job and would be free to undertake our work at once. This would be a very great help to me as I am anxious to get the other work of painting and whitewashing done while we have the hopes of the school free to do it. You will see it would be foolish of me to undertake this work until the other is done.

The cleaning work if done ahead of the other work will have to be done over again and I would like, if possible, to avoid this.

I am pleased to be able to report the work of the dentist is going along nicely also the work in connection with the need for glasses to aid the sight of five of the children.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of April 8 and subsequent correspondence regarding repairs required at the Chapleau Indian Residential School, it is desired that you arrange with Mr. L. Bignucolo, of Chapleau, to visit the school and prepare a bill of materials which will be required for the repairs. You should only consider the repairs that are absolutely necessary to prevent damage to the building. Our funds are limited and consequently the cost of the repairs must be kept as low as possible.

When Mr. Bignucolo has prepared the bill of materials you may obtain prices from firms on your approved list. If there are any materials required which are not handled by any firm on your approved list you should so advise me.

Mr. Bignucolo should also give you, for our consideration, an estimate of the cost of the labour required to make the necessary repairs.

The list of materials should be fully detailed and their cost together with the name of the firm quoting should be submitted to the Department for our decision before any work is done.

Please give this matter your immediate attention.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:-

You may recall my visit to your office last Spring and our talk about a power machine for sawing fire wood at the school.

You told me it would not be possible to buy a new one. Then you very kindly advised me to try and see what could be done in the way of getting a used outfit. I tried but could not find a suitable one.

I have now gone thoroughly into the matter, and have a scheme approved by the Indian Agent, after consulting the best experts here, whereby we can still use a spare motor we have on hand.

If you will permit him to expend not more than sixty dollar we can have connection made to our Electric System and install this motor to run the saw we have on hand.

I trust you may be able to allow us this amount and so overcome our need for a new outfit next year.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
Chapleau November 29th, 1938.

Sir,

I beg leave to enclose letter received from the Rev. Principal of the Chapleau Indian Residential School relative to a Power Motor for cutting wood at the School.

The use of the Spare Motor which they have on hand at the school will do the work nicely, but the cost of putting in the extra wiring and switch box will entail some costs and the Engineer of the Power company here advizes me that this can be done at a cost slightly less than $60.00 and I would like to reccomend that this work be done, and by using this motor considerable costs would be saved when the cost of a new machine for the sawing machine is considered. At the present time they have no machine to cut wood and it is very unsatisfactory and they need a power plant very badly and by using this spare motor they would have ample power and could use the old sawing machine as it is in good order.

From rough tests made as to flow through the pipe it would average about 1,000 gallons per hour. The school contains up to a maximum of 100 pupils with probably 25 teachers and helpers. There are baths, laundry, toilets, etc., and it is also supplied to the barn for watering stock and to the Principal's residence. I would point out that this water supply provides entirely inadequate fire protection. Further with all the pumping equipment in the boiler room it might easily be rendered useless in case of fire.

The location of the source of supply of water is considered the most suitable to obtain good water and if taken from the river on Indian Reserve lands is very liable to be contaminated and is subject to contamination.

Future trouble can be anticipated especially where breaks have occurred in the present galvanized pipe which is now practically worn out and in a short while will have to be replaced. I would suggest placing the proposed new pipe line farther away from the bank of river and the General Manager of the Power Company informed me there would be no objection to the proposed line about as indicated on the plan. It would appear desirable to obtain an agreement from the Power Company to lay and maintain the pipe line. I should suggest replacing the pipe line by a Universal 4 inch cast iron pipe located as shown on sketch or closer to the windmill as the Power Company will admit, to avoid extra digging. The cast iron pipe should not scale like the present pipe and should last considerably longer and it is easy to install. For a distance of about 800 feet from the lake the trench will have to be dug from 12 to 18 feet and the remaining distance to a depth of approximately 6½ feet to be below frost. I was informed the digging would all be through a very fine sandy soil and surface indications would bear this out. The intake should be laid on boulders or rock to keep it well above the mud bed of the stream. These can easily be obtained.

It would be very desirable and would recommend the pumping equipment be installed in a small separate building approximately 12 x 12 feet situated a short distance from the school which could operate with ease even in case of fire. The present machinery in the building could be used and transferred at very little expense. There should also be a nearby outside hydrant. Memorandum:

Mr. Mills

Re: Water Supply System, Chapleau Residential School, Chapleau, Ont.

In accordance with your letter of September 13th, I beg to submit the following report on the water supply system for the above noted school. The water supply for this school is obtained above a dam in the Chapleau river by a gravity system through a 3 inch galvanized iron pipe as shown on accompanying sketch plan. The water is then stored in a horizontal cylindrical tank 4 ft x 15 ft. in the boiler room section of building and by air pressure water is forced through the mains in the building. The town of Chapleau obtains its domestic water supply farther up stream on the same river and I am informed that tests made each year show the water fit to drink.

The dam and surrounding land is owned by the Chapleau Light and Power Company who apparently have allowed the school to obtain water without any written agreement. The intake pipe goes through the wing wall of their dam. I understand when the pipe line was installed in 1920 the former dam was of wood construction and about 10 years ago this dam was washed out and a modern concrete dam is now installed raising the water level over 2 feet over previous height. The wing wall of the dam is through very fine loose sand and the Power Company do not wish it disturbed in any way.

The shut off valve is now about 8 feet in the lake and end of intake pipe about 40 feet farther on now on a bed of stone about 4 feet above the bottom of the river. This intake valve will now neither open or shut and was informed the end of the intake pipe was formerly on the bed of the river where silt could get in.

I am informed the pipe first broke in 1923 and other breaks occurred in 1927 all about 225 feet from dam and are apparently caused by the pipe line being too close to the edge of bank of river and underground springs coming out at foot of bank have caused the earth to settle and pipe to break and also there was considerable bend in pipe line at this point. The Indian Agent stated there was a large amount of scale and some silt in the pipe where the breaks were repaired which he doubt is stopping the flow in the pipe and will likely in a short time make flow less than the requirements for domestic use. Re: Chapleau Indian Residential School water supply.

We have now the report of Mr. McKnight who visited the above school and made an investigation into the water supply. A copy of the Engineer's report is attached together with a blueprint plan showing the present pipeline and the one which is proposed. It is noted that the existing pipeline, although it supplies the present domestic needs, is filled in with scale and silt and is quite inadequate for fire protection and will have to be replaced very soon. Breaks are occurring apparently due to underground springs causing the earth to settle. There is further the danger of the electric pumps, which are in the boiler room section, being rendered useless through short circuiting.

Mr. McKnight's recommendation for the installation of new pipeline with hydrant, shut-off valves etc., pump-house, wiring and changing machinery, engineering and other incidental expenses would cost an estimated amount of $2,600. Excavation .................................................. 550.00
Backfilling .................................................. 125.00

$2,600.00

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter as above.

I have gone into the matter fully with the Rev. Canon Vale and he is willing to co-operate in every possible way.

The amount could be reduced considerably by using the boys at the school to do most of the excavating and back filling; by doing this a saving of $675.00 could be made on these two items alone.

The engineer at the school could assist with wiring and changing over of machinery and part of the engineering of the whole job, and thus reduce this part of the cost.

We thought the best scheme would be for the department to provide the pipe this year, which with the assistance of the school engineer could be laid this fall and by plugging both ends of the pipe, it could be left in a safe condition until next year, when the other incidental parts could be supplied, and installed.

The pipe is the main cost, and the length of this cannot be reduced, but they would be responsible for the laying, providing a list of pipe joints, with pipe sizes and levels, of the pipe could be specified, although both at what the pipe would stand at the dam, and where it would enter the school, these could be secured from Mr. McKnight, the engineer who inspected the job.

By doing it this way I estimate the entire job could be done for about $1,850.00 which could be spread over the year or next, without a complete list of the valves etc., that would be needed it is impossible to estimate this any closer, but I would see that any incidentals were kept to the minimum.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Chapleau Indian Residential School Water Supply.

With regard to your memorandum of August 29th in connection with the above, I would first point out that, due to the war, the prices of materials generally have increased and the estimate given in our Engineer McKnight's report, attached to our memorandum of October 20th, 1939, would have to be increased about 15% for 6" Universal cast iron pipe.

Regarding the last paragraph of the letter from the Indian Agent at Chapleau, Engineer McKnight took only a few levels along the proposed main line to obtain information as to depth of trench as given in his report, and obtain an estimate of cost as he considered that if and when the proposed pipe line was approved, the route would be finally located and staked out and levels given. In his report of October 26th, 1939, he points out that the surrounding land and dam at the intake belong to the Chapleau Light and Power Company and that it was desirable to obtain an easement from the Company for the new pipe line or other necessary buildings.

As to depth of trench for the pipe, a minimum cover of 4½ feet over the pipe is necessary owing to frost conditions. The depth at lake level at the intake and also below the ground level at the school would be 7 feet with a fairly uniform slope between these two points as it is a gravity system for water supply.

The general layout for a gravity system is indicated on the attached sketch. This involves digging a trench for a distance of about 300 feet at the lake end to a depth of from 15 to over 20 feet which is too dangerous for semi-skilled school to undertake. However, the Power Company might allow the pipe line to come near the end of the wing wall as indicated in red on the sketch plan, where there probably would not be an excessive depth for necessary excavation by senior boys under supervision. A gravity line would have to be properly staked on the ground by an engineer before operations commenced.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
The first step would apparently be the securing of an easement from the Power Company and which should not be difficult in view of the fact that the 3" main is already located across the Company's property.

It is noted from your memorandum that $1,000 might be made available this year and in such case, we would recommend that the pipe be purchased as soon as it is certain an easement can be obtained. The 1,300 feet of pipe required will, under present prices, cost between $950 and $1,000.

Mr. Mills, in his memorandum, refers to an alternative plan under which the water would be pumped directly from the lake to the school building and which would have the advantage of lighter excavation for the pipeline. This method, however, is not recommended as it is not as satisfactory or economical in the long run as a gravity line to a pump house located near the school, at which point pressure can be boosted to the extent necessary.

Dear Sir:

I am anxious to overcome the drafts coming down through the ceiling of my house, which is a menace to our health in the winter. The cold winds have started and we need some protection this winter.

Last winter we had a lot of trouble from the ice forming on the roof and the water backing up under the shingles and leaking through.

I talked this matter over with the Indian Agent. He advised me to write and see if you would provide insulation to put over the ceiling. He assures me that would do away with all that trouble. I have measured the ceiling of my house and find it is 23 feet by 25 feet space that would need to be covered.

I have taken up the matter of cost with the local merchants and find the material could be supplied for not more than forty dollars. We can do the work of putting it in place if you will meet the first cost of material.

I might explain this is an old house, brought here from the former school site. In my opinion it would be economy to have this repair done now before greater damage is caused to the roof by accumulation of the ice during the coming winter.

Dear Sir,

Memorandum:

Re: Water Supply, Chapleau Indian Residential School

In reference to your memorandum of the 18th instant, with enclosures, I may say that Indian Agent Matter's suggestion appears to be feasible and it is considered that the new pipe line should be laid as connected to the pump in the school for the sum mentioned, $1,000.00, provided that no unforeseen difficulties are encountered in placing the intake in the lake or in excavating in what is stated to be a very light sandy soil, possibly requiring shoring throughout the entire distance.

A subsequent inspection might be necessary when the work is nearing completion.

Our engineer can leave for Chapleau at any time but we should be glad to know when it would be convenient for the Indian Affairs Branch to have him go.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed is the Labour return for the week ending July 12th.

Satisfactory progress is being made; we have got over the first and worst obstacle, that of getting the intake placed in position, five feet under water.

Also we have laid about one hundred feet of pipe, this is now into the deepest cut, and about thirty feet per day is all we can lay, but soon we will be out into the open, then it will speed up considerably.

You may note that I am paying one of the labourers 30¢ per day, and the rest only 25¢, this chap is the fastest worker of the bunch, and I have him working in the bottom of the trench, which is at the present time about sixteen feet deep, work there has to be done fast to get the pipe into place before the sides have a chance to slide in and he is doing a good job, I am connecting up all the pipe myself, and spending all day on the job, as in some places the sides had to be sheeted and I did not want to leave anyone else to be responsible for the safety of the men in the trench.

I will have enough money for wages for this week, but will need about $175.00 more to finish the job, we may get away with less and if possible I will see to it, but after all the other expenses are met I think we will be inside our estimate.

Your obedient servant,
P. Matters, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

The situation at the local Indian Residential school with regard to Fire has been a thing constantly in my mind.

The distance from the school to the nearest point that water could be taken from the river is such that only one line of hose could be used by the town fire pump.

When working on the new water system at the same school, I got the boys of the school with horses to scoop out and make a roadway about 200 feet long to a point in the river about halfway between the bridge (where water would be taken in the past, and at which point, there is a direct lift of ten feet to the pump) and the school, they also made a platform, cribbed in and filled with stone, on which the truck could stand when pumping.

This means that from the new point two lines of hose, with considerably more pressure can be operated, as it is down to water level with no initial lift.

To make a good job of this, and make it safe for the truck to go down, it should have a coating of gravel the whole length, as it is all through soft sand, and I would ask your authority to hire a truck and a driver for two days, at a cost of $25.00 to do this, the boys from the school can load and spread the gravel, at no cost, and so far the whole job has not cost us one cent.

Your obedient servant

Memorandum:

Mr. Mills

Re: Chapleau Indian Residential School Water Supply

In accordance with instructions given in your letter of the 6th instant, I beg to report that I proceeded to Chapleau, Ontario, on the 18th instant, and spent part of the 12th and all of the 13th, 14th and 16th instants at the above school, in connection with preparations for the installation of the new 4" gravity water supply pipe.

Mr. Fife, Manager of the Chapleau Power Company, which owns the dam near the school, indicated on the ground the minimum distance from the end of the wing wall that the Company would allow the pipe line to pass. With this restriction, a line was run and staked on the ground as shown on the attached blueprint. Levels were taken on this line, a profile was prepared and cuts required for trenching indicated as required on the ground. The line was carried to the rear of the Power Company's house, as shown on the plan, requiring a small sweep which can be taken up easily in the Universal pipe joints. At Mr. Fife's request, a 4" x 4" x 1" tee is being placed opposite this house to provide for future connection.

The total distance between the junction with the existing 3" main near the school building and the point of emergence of the pipe into the lake is 1070 feet. As 1500 lineal feet of 4" pipe was purchased for the job, there will be some 200 lineal feet surplus after providing for the intake lengths and a few lengths to be held for emergencies. It is considered that at present the 3" main leading into the building, which passes under the laundry wing, need not be replaced, as it is in good condition and has been adequate until pump house be constructed outside the school, as previously suggested by Mr. McKeight and the pumping equipment be transferred to this location. To provide for this, a 4" x 4" x 4" tee is being placed approximately 100 feet from the school in the new line.

As the line is a gravity one, a continuous fall has been provided for in the grades laid out. This involves a heavy cut through a sandy knoll for a distance of about 300 feet from the intake, - the maximum cut being 15.8'. In this distance it is proposed to reduce........

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Water Supply, Chapleau Indian Residential Schools

With further reference to your notation of the 4th instant on Dr. McGill's memorandum to you of June 3rd in regard to the above matter, I am attaching hereto for your information duplicate copies of a report submitted by Mr. H.A. Sparks covering his recent visit to this School.

In this connection it might be noted that after discussion on the ground with an officer of the Power Company, permission was secured to utilize a more direct route for the pipe line with a consequent shortening of the latter by approximately 800 feet.

Under this arrangement, a line suitable to all parties concerned was staked out and levels for the pipe line marked on the ground. The Indian Agent has also ordered necessary lumber, pipe specials and jointing material required. The installation was fully discussed on the ground with Indian Agent Matters and School Engineer Mayo who were satisfied that necessary excavation, pipe-laying and testing could be carried out without further supervision for the present.

You will note that provision has been made for connection close to the School to the existing 3" main which passes under the laundry wing. Tunnelling under this wing would be required to carry the 6" main to the pump room. This added expense is not considered necessary as it is recommended that as soon as possible the pumping equipment be moved from the School to a small pump house to be erected outside the main building, as already recommended in previous reports.

Dear Sir;

Enclosed are the weekly returns of Labour for work done on the new water supply system at the Chapleau Indian Residential School, also a credit voucher covering them.

Work this last week has not progressed so favourably as in previous weeks; we struck much more trouble than I had anticipated in crossing the highway.

Apparently the traffic over this section had so worked the sand under and on both sides that it continually caved in, and we had to resort to shoring up the sides again, but we got through alright without anyone being hurt, beyond being caught in the slide when the sides came in, several, including myself had to be dug out after being caught up to the waist in this sand.

At the present time we are in much better going, and I will try get along with the money already advanced for wages.

There are several matters need my attention on the C.M.R. line, and I am leaving here to-night en route to all the points along the line from Sudbury to Oba; this I expect will take a week, and in the meantime I am leaving the men working for two days under the supervision of Canon Vale, to fill in at some of the deep places we passed through, the boys from the school are helping by filling in the other places.

Your obedient servant

F. Matters

Dear Sir;

Attached are pay list and credit voucher forms for the wages paid on the new water supply at The Chapleau Indian Residential School, for the week ending Aug. 2nd.

The work is going along fine now, and I think we can safely say that our troubles are behind us, as now the trench is only about six feet deep and we are laying about 75 feet per day.

At this rate it will take about five or six days to complete the job, and at present I have not got enough money on hand to pay for this length of time. It will take another £300 to be on the safe side, but I am having them continue as quickly as possible and will pay them when it is possible to get the extra money needed.

Dear Sir;

Now that the water supply is installed at the Chapleau Residential School at approximately the estimate, a closer check of which I will make on my return from taking a mental patient to Hospital in the early part of next week.

I would recommend that repairs be proceeded with at once to the fire box of the main boiler at the school.

The fire brick is badly burned out, and it will take about 250 fire bricks, and 250 lb. of fire lime to repair this; the total cost should be in the neighborhood of $75.00.

The work will be done by the school engineer, so no labour costs are involved.

I suggest that it be done at once, because soon it will be necessary to have a fire going in the building, and it will then be harder to get a chance to get inside the fire box.

Dear Sir,

Now that the new water supply has been installed at the Chapleau Residential School, and repairs made to the main fire box, I think the matter of sleeping accommodation should now be considered.

The present beds are of a very old type institutional bed; I am enclosing a sketch of the shape and sizes of the spring; you will notice that no side rails are used, the frame of the spring being fitted with cones to connect to the head and foot of the bed.

I have made enquiries locally about getting this type of spring, but the local merchants have been unable to locate a manufacturer who can supply this kind, and I have come to the conclusion that it would be better to budget on changing over all of them to standard single size beds, over a period of four or five years.

They have been in constant use for over twenty years, the only replacement having been some straw mattresses supplied quite a while ago, and I am afraid that to continue trying to get parts for these outmoded designs will cost more in the end than will the replacements.

I would recommend that whatever money is left of the school appropriation be spent on purchasing new bed outfits. I have apprised locally of $18.00 per set, bed, spring and mattress of the

Dear Sir,

The automatic control for the pumping of water into the storage tank at the St. John's Indian Residential School, has not been working at all satisfactory for some time.

Repairs have been made by the engineer, and parts have been purchased from the makers of the equipment, but without satisfaction, at times it will cut in and not cut out when supposed to, at other times it does not cut in and the school water system is not supplied, to operate it manually would mean having a man on duty there almost continually which can hardly be done.

I find that the Fairbanks Morse company can supply a suitable control of much simpler design at a cost of approximately $8.00, and would recommend that authority be given the school authorities to purchase one of these.

When at the school recently Mr. Bristow was shown the outfit and possibly he can give you further details if necessary.

Dear Sir,

During a very cold spell, last night when the temperature was officially 81 degrees below Zero, two of the hot water heating coils at The St. John's Indian Residential School, were frozen and broken.

The engineer at the school is in bed sick, so I had to have the local plumber do what he could so that heat could be secured as soon as possible; he is endeavouring to separate the broken sections, and by using the good ones, and inserting some new ones he expects to be able to get it going again today.

The weather is still very cold, and I trust that my action in having emergency repairs made meets with your approval.

Your obedient servant

F. Matters

Dear Sir;

This will acknowledge receipt of the above letter, I have made a survey at the St John's Indian Residential School, and the following are my observations.

The roof of the school needs repairing in several places, and shingles fastened down in others. I had a carpenter look over this work and he gave me an estimate of $30.00 for the labour and materials.

The 20 new beds provided for in the estimates should be provided if possible to secure, I made enquiry from the same source I purchased last year and was advised that it was still possible to get them if ordered soon; this is 20 new beds and Mattresses complete with Springs; the condition of the old beds is such, that we ought to make every effort to replace this number each year until all are changed.

The residence of the Principle is in very bad shape, originally it was a shingled building and these are peeling and curling off; to make a more or less permanent job of it, I would recommend that it be covered with heavy Insul-Bric Siding; this will last for a long time, and cut down on any or most of the painting and repairs for this next ten years, the estimated cost of this job is about $300.00 to $350.00 depending upon where the material is available.

The Secretary

Dear Sir,

In making a report of the material required for the maintenance of the buildings at The St. John's Indian Residential School, Chapleau, I omitted to include roofing for some of the buildings.

The roofing on the Feed room, repair shop and machine house, is pretty well perished and the life all gone out of it.

They are covered with roll roofing, with a smooth surface, and must have been on for a considerable length of time, as now it is all dry, torn and cracked, allowing water to go through, patching is not of much use, as the condition is general all over the roof.

In covering it again, I would recommend using heavy rock surfaced roofing, 80 lbs. to the roll; this I find can be purchased in Chapleau at a cost of $6.75 per roll, the original material, heavy mica surfaced roofing can be had for $3.50 per roll, but I would recommend the former, as it will stand the snow and rain twice as long as the latter.

In all 15 rolls will be required, and I think that the school people could put this on themselves, if the material were supplied.

Your obedient servant

F. Matters
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

The Insul brick siding having arrived for the residence of the Principle, at the Chapleau Indian Residential School, I at once asked all local contractors and carpenters for a tender to cover the labour of putting it on.

I could only get one tender for an immediate start on the work, this was necessary as the weather has turned cold, and it should be got on as soon as possible, this tender from Bignucoli Bros. was for $90.00 for all labour involved, under the circumstances I accepted it, and have got the job started, it will be completed in a week or so with three men working at it.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa,

A week or so ago the principle of the Chapleau Indian Residential School reported to me that the lower part of the heater, used to provide hot water for the school had cracked.

I examined the heater along with the school engineer, and thought it possible to have the jacket heater repaired, and subsequently got a plumber to look it over and provide me with an estimate of the cost of repairs.

We found that the lower part of the heater being all in one piece that it would be necessary to get a new part including grates, and with the cost of installation of the parts his quotation was $100.00.

This appeared to me to be about the price of a new heater, so I made further enquiries and find that a similar jacket heater may be purchased for $100.00 installed.

When there I overlooked getting the name of the heater, but no doubt you will have it on file, but I would recommend that a new jacket heater be supplied either by local or direct purchase in the near future.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.
