Mr. F. Matters, Indian Agent, Chapleau, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, please let me know the name and address of the firm from whom you obtained the quotation of $100.00 for a new jacket heater for the Chapleau School. When replying you should give full information regarding the type of heater required.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report the Doctor gave me permission to take my quarterly report into the hospital yesterday to have it signed by Indian Agent P. Matters.

I am pleased to be able to inform you he was able to be up for a short time and so was able to attend to the work of signing the report which I then forwarded to you by post.

I also discussed with him the matter of our having one BILLY goat here all the summer and no word yet of the females that were to be sent. This animal by himself is of no use to us. He makes extra work and no returns. May I ask you what plans you have in the matter of sending us the females or do you wish this animal sent somewhere to be of use.

I also pointed out to Mr. Matters, we received the paint asked for, but to date no word has come in regard to the rock wool Insulation asked for. This would be a great saving of fuel to us if it can be given us. It will relieve the situation in regard to shortage of fuel this winter.

Re: Fire at Chapleau Schools

Yesterday afternoon, February 1st., the Principal of the above school called me on the telephone and advised that they had had a chimney fire, but that it was apparently out.

I requested him to keep a sharp look out around the chimney to see that it did not break out in any other place, and authorized him to get the chemicals necessary to recharge some of the fire extinguishers that had been used.

About 6:30 p.m. I received another call from the school advising me that the fire had broken out around the chimney in the attic.

I called the local fire brigade at once, and sent the fire truck with several of the firemen to the school, and got the balance of the firemen down in a couple of taxis; we arrived within ten minutes of the call going in with all the equipment that might be needed.

On arrival we found that the fire had started between the attic floor and the ceiling of the second storey, on two sides of the chimney, the school equipment was being used effectively by the staff on one side, but on examination found that the other side was the worst, it had been used as a store room, and when the goods were moved we found about ten feet square of the floor was burning briskly.

The Chapleau Fire brigade took over, and after cutting out the floor and being able to get the water in between the floor and ceiling, it was finally extinguished after about an hour's work; they used the school equipment which worked very well except for one length of hose which split and had to be disconnected.

Over.
The main damage consists of:
- Ceiling of second floor burned through, 10' x 10'
- Floor of attic, beams, etc. burned,
- Ceiling of ground floor and basement, walls of first and second storeys damaged by smoke and water.
- Chimney cracked above roof, needs pointing.

I left instructions to have an extra man stay on duty all night, and to leave the hose connected and ready for use; this was done, but no further fire developed.

None of the children suffered any ill effects; they were orderly and under control of the staff, who moved them outside, then later into one of the rooms that was dry; the older boys helped considerably and without any excitement.

The Chapleau Volunteer Fire Brigade are to be commended for their prompt response to the call, and the way in which they worked when they got to the school. In the opinion of both the Fire Chief and myself another ten or fifteen minutes would probably have meant that the fire would have spread and got out of control entirely.

I had made arrangements to leave here on Thursday, February 3rd., to escort a sick Indian from Sudbury to Manitowaning hospital, and had intended to go right through, but I will try to have Mr. Johnston from Manitowaning meet me at Little Current, then I will be able to turn back from there, and will be in Chapleau again either on February 5th. or 6th.

I visited the school again today, and left the school engineer to take up a list of material that will be required to repair the building; and I have also asked a local contractor to do the same with an estimate on the labour costs; when I return I will check the results with my own and advise you more fully as to repairs; I would estimate off-hand that the damage would amount to about $300.00.

If you think it desirable to send someone from the Branch to report on the school, please advise and I will arrange to meet him; also if any other information is needed I will get it for you.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
February 4, 1944.

Mr. F. Matters, Indian Agent, Chapleau, Ont.

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to the fire at the Chapleau Indian Residential School.

Our experience is that whenever a fire, no matter how small at first, occurs at an Indian residential school every possible endeavour should be made to see that it is fully extinguished. Apparently this was not done at the Chapleau School and I am inclined to feel a more thorough examination of the building at the time the chimney fire occurred would have resulted in saving considerable expense and trouble later. However, we are glad to note that, as a result of the splendid efforts of the Chapleau fire brigade, the second blaze was brought under control in a short time. It would be appreciated if you could extend to the Chapleau Volunteer Fire Brigade our appreciation for their services.

I presume that you will communicate with me again when the extent of the damage has been finally determined.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa,

In going over the school to get the details mentioned, I had the School Principal and the Engineer, and in any case that I have suggested that the work could be done by the staff, they concurred. I had the contractors' estimates with me, and checked all the parts where work was proposed, and had these submitted in sections, so that parts that had to be done would be done first and others omitted if it was thought necessary.

There is only one contractor here at the present time who has the material and labour available; they could start with the papering and decorating at once, and with the carpenter work in two weeks.

I can imagine that it will be rather difficult for you to determine from the above report just what ought to be done, without seeing the building itself; however, if there is any other information you require I will be pleased to procure it for you.

Possibly the best solution would be for you to place whatever funds are available for this job at my disposal, and I will see that the most urgent parts are repaired first, and that the money is used to the best advantage; I have had some experience in this type of supervision as when in business we did a good deal of this work.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.
If finances are available there are several other parts of the building that could be improved at the same time, to put everything into good shape for some years; these are not due to the fire.

**Principal Office:** It is rather run down with regard to appearance, and could do with a general redecoration, this would be the walls and ceiling done with one coat of washable Duro paint, one coat of varnish on the woodwork, and the floors sanded and finished with two coats of varnish, total cost of $62.60

**Main Hall:** The walls need to painted again due to smoke marking, this can be done by the school staff, the ceiling which is of Beaver board is warped, this type of construction is dangerous in case of a fire, in my opinion all the ceilings ought to be of gyproc or other fire resisting materials, especially in a case like the hall, which extends from one stairway to the other, the estimated cost of this change would be $37.50

**Attic Floors:** There are four sections of the attic, which are used as store rooms, where the floor is not finished, the joists being exposed, consequently the goods stored are not piled up neatly and are hard to move in case of a fire, if the joists were covered with softwood flooring it would be safer and cleaner, it would take 2,000 feet B.M. of tongue and grooved flooring to do this, the lumber at the present time is selling at $75.00 per thousand, the work could be done by the school staff.

This far exceeds my original estimate made the day after the fire, but is governed by the damage that became more apparent when the Beaver board dried out and began to warp, most of the repairs are proposed to be made with gyproc instead of Beaver board, I found that the latter material had carried the fire along the back of the board and thus created a dangerous fire hazard.

In several places I have suggested that Beaver board be used again to effect repairs, this is more of a temporary expedient to keep the expense down at the present time, if and when it is possible to get the necessary appropriation I would recommend that all the ceilings be made safer by changing to gyproc.
Sewing room. 6 sheets of Beaver board are needed here repaired, and I think this also could be done by the staff of the school.

Girls recreation room. The ceiling of this room in the basement is damaged by water, 50% of it will have to be renewed; I would recommend that the whole ceiling be replaced with gyproc, rather than replace half of the Beaver board, a price of $90.00 is quoted for the complete job, removing old material and recovering.

Main dining Room. This also is in the basement, and the entire ceiling will need to be renewed, due to water damage, the tender price for this is $104.00 for materials and labour, using gyproc instead of Beaver board.

Reception room. The ceiling and one wall of this room, which is papered is damaged and the paper hanging loose, it is suggested that the ceiling be painted and the walls papered, a price of $59.3c is quoted to do this and also sand and finish the floor with two coats of varnish, the latter part is not essential but would be an improvement, the ceiling and walls will have to be done and if finances are available I would recommend that it all be done.

Ceiling of Entrance vestibule. This hall damaged and hanging in places, it could be replaced with gyproc at a total cost of $10.50, and I would recommend that this be done.

Cloak room. The ceiling of this room, which is upstairs needs to be replaced and can be done for a cost of $11.80, using gyproc, this I recommend.

Fire protection equipment. One length of hose was found to be defective, and I would recommend that it be replaced with one of the following:

- 50 feet, as above double wall = $60.00

Regarding your request for a quotation on a new chimney to be built at the Indian Echo I, we have gone into this matter and are prepared to quote and do the work. However, should our price be satisfactory, we will be notified within two weeks.

June 28th, 1944

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa,

Some months ago we had a fire at the Chapleau Residential School, which was started by a faulty and overheated chimney.

When other repairs were being made I tried to get a price on the rebuilding of the present chimney, which is of single brick construction and entirely unsafe.

At that time I was not successful due to lack of material and skilled labour, but now have a quotation from the only people who will be able to do the work this year and theirs is a restricted tender with regard to time for acceptance.

After the fire I thoroughly examined the chimney, and there is no doubt that it needs to be rebuilt; the brick is of poor quality, and being of only single thickness constitutes a fire hazard any time that a fire is going in either the cook stove or the bake ovens.

I propose, and the tender is based on the building of a chimney outside the building, in the corner on the North side formed by the girls entrance and the bakery, this will mean a little longer pipe to the chimney from the cook stove, but shorter from the bake oven and all exposed where they can be watched, the chimney will be carried up through the eave and be properly flaged and finished.

Attached is a copy of the tender, I have not had any experience in the building of chimneys so cannot offer any opinion as to the reasonableness of the price, it will be higher here than in Ottawa or other points where the freight on material is less and skilled labour can be found, this man had to be brought in for other work and his expenses are consequently higher. If it is found satisfactory and money is available I would recommend that the work be done as soon as possible.

P. Matters, Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
June 12, 1944.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

RE: Chapleau Indian Residential School,
Chapleau Indian Agency, Electoral District of Algoma West.

Some months ago there was a fire at this school and only the strenuous efforts on the part of the Principal, staff and pupils saved the building. Indian Agent Matters reports definitely that the cause of the fire was a defective chimney. He has thoroughly examined this chimney and states there is no doubt it needs to be rebuilt, as the brick is of poor quality and only single thickness. For your information I enclose a copy of tender which Mr. Matters has received from Smith and Chapleau Limited, Chapleau, Ontario. As Mr. Matters points out, the price is higher than could be obtained at more accessible points, but all the brick has to be freighted to Chapleau and skilled labour has also to be brought in from outside.

From all the reports we have received it appears essential that a new chimney should be built at this school and I should, therefore, appreciate receiving your approval to accept the tender of Smith and Chapleau, who offer to do the entire job, including carpenter work on roofs, base construction, scaffolding, flashing and all materials, at a cost of $1850.

Director.

Gentlemen:

Will you kindly ship as soon as possible the following parts for an "Oxford portable bake oven," #72-C, also marked A B & C "" on the firebox.

Right and left side heating chambers, complete from the outside of the firebox to the entrance to the flues, these are of sheet metal; the flues inside the casing are alright; also complete set of angle iron strips used in support for the firebrick above the firebox and below the oven section.

As these are for a residential school which depends upon the oven for the baking of bread etc., I would appreciate your early attention and shipment; please invoice in triplicate copies to this office, and address shipment to:

Rev. A. J. Valls
Indian Residential School
Chapleau Ont.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.
The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa

During the summer holidays the engineer at the Chapleau Residential School has been making repairs to the fireboxes of the furnace and Bake ovens.

This morning I received a call to visit the school and examine the condition of the firebox of the Bake oven, and found it in very bad condition; the heating chambers at both sides of the firebox had been completely burnt out at one end of each, also the angle iron strips across the casing for the purpose of holding the firebrick in place was gone in some places on each strip.

Both Mr. Arnell who was with me at the time and myself agreed that nothing short of new parts were necessary to get the oven into working condition again, and I have taken the liberty of ordering the parts from the manufacturer.

It is going to take a little time in any case to get them, and although they were going to try to make temporary repairs they would be for a very short time, due to the ends of the chambers being burnt out completely. I trust that you will endorse my action in thus going ahead without your permission which would have been requested in the ordinary course of events.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.

In my report dated January 7th., regarding conditions with regard to food at the above school, I mentioned that I thought more eggs were needed, and would get the data for a larger hen house.

I am enclosing a plan provided by the Experimental Farm Service for a house 20' X 36', which with the present capacity ought to provide enough space for 200 hens.

I think that if it is possible that it would be wise to supply this material and help to build, so that the onus of providing a sufficiently varied and adequate diet for the children, will be placed upon the school authorities.

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, enclosing plan of a hen-house with a sufficient capacity to provide space for raising 200 hens.

I discussed this matter with Mr. Roy this morning, and before giving further consideration to the Principal's request it would be appreciated if you would talk the matter over fully with him.

While the cost of eggs is probably high at the present time, there are often periods when eggs can be procured quite reasonably, and at such times the expense of raising hens is not profitable. Again, it is not exactly a simple matter to raise 200 hens. It will be necessary to have someone on the staff who knows how to properly raise them. Re: File 65-1-5, March 3rd, 1946.

In reply to your letter as above, I had a thorough discussion on the matter with the Rev. A. J. Vale on Saturday afternoon, March 17th, regarding it.

He has kept accurate records of cost of keeping the hens and the value of the eggs and fowl produced, on a monthly basis, and these were a great help in reaching a conclusion on the matter.

Based on the 50 hens they have been in the habit of keeping, I find that the cost for feed, chicks etc., without any labour charge amounted to $124.62, and the value of eggs produced, at current market prices, was $150.13, plus about 150 lbs. of chicken and fowl used in place of meat, to the value of $42.00.

The present farm instructor is qualified to and has had enough experience to look after more, and on the basis that 200 hens would produce a sufficient number of eggs, it is reasonable to assume that a saving as against buying them, would be affected to the extent of about $260.00.

Along with this advantage, the boys would get more experience in looking after chickens, but I doubt if this would benefit more than about 10% of the boys who did the work.

Against the initial cost and maintenance, which I would estimate at $2,500.00 with 5% for repairs etc., per year, can be placed the expected saving of $250.00.

The report as prepared by the Red Cross indicated a definite lack of eggs in the diet, and I was probably looking at the necessary objective, rather than at the best way to reach that goal.

On a straight economic analysis, the expenditure of so much capital, in view of the limited returns, is not sound, but is there any other alternative to ensure the provision of a more adequate diet.

I have in mind now the matter of Children's Allowances, if the schools are to be paid all or part of this as guardians of the children, then I think this will cover the all round expanded diet as recommended, and all schools should then be able to raise the standard of their meals to a point, that would compare favourably with one set out by the Branch as being adequate.

As I see it School conditions in general will have to be dramatically improved, to induce Indian parents to allow their children to go to school, as each child going to school will mean the loss of the allowance, and this is going to appear as a very large sacrifice to the Indians.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 26, 1945.

BASMENT LAUNDRY.

Branch circuit cutouts are heavily overfused.
The floor of this section is of a concrete mix nature and the operators using the hand electric irons are liable to severe shock should the metal parts of the irons become alive through faulty cords etc. We would recommend that mats of rubber or wood be supplied for the operators.

Wall receptacles are supplied for the connection of the electric hand irons. Should the operator leave the room without first disconnecting the cord from the receptacle, there would be a possibility of fire originating in the cloth cover or board. We would suggest that a switch and pilot light be added to each receptacle.

ELECTRIC MOTORS, General.

All motors should be grounded to conduit supply or water pipe.
Fuses in motor switches should be reduced to the lowest possible for adequate protection of each motor.
The present method of control of motors meets the requirements but we would strongly recommend the installation of thermal type controls in order to provide the maximum protection should minor grounds or motor winding faults appear.

OUTBUILDINGS.

Remove added extension cords from circuits in residence and install wall receptacles where required for portable devices.
Ground all conduit in stable, also Armoured Cable in chicken coops etc., to driven ground rods.
Remove armoured cable from hay mow and replace with rigid conduit and dust-tite type hub fitting.
Remove sub-standard wiring from root cellar and replace with lead covered wiring in conduit.
Overhaul wood cutting wiring and equipment in yard and drive rods for grounding of same.
Mr. F. Matters,
Indian Agent, Chapleau.

Subject: St. John's Indian Residential School,
Chapleau, Ontario.

MAIN SERVICE and DISTRIBUTION.

Main wire shows evidence of overheating; Resolder wire into copper lug.
Ground main neutral wire and metal parts to water pipe.
All stored materials to be kept clear of service equipment.
Reduce all sub-feeder cartridge fuses to not more than maximum capacity of wire.

BRANCH CIRCUIT DISTRIBUTION CENTRES.

The branch circuit distribution centres consist of obsolete type open cutouts built into partitions throughout the building. We would strongly recommend that these assemblies be replaced with standard dead front, solid neutral, type panels.
The majority of the branch circuit cutouts are heavily overfused. All branch circuit fuses to be reduced to not more than 15 amps. Check load on each circuit and if overloaded, split into two or more circuits.
The branch circuit wiring is of rigid conduit type. All circuits should be tested individually and if grounds are indicated, circuit wires should be replaced.

CONVENIENCE OUTLETS.

At the time that this building was originally wired very few wall convenience receptacles were installed. Due to the absence of these devices we find that there is a large amount of sub-standard cord extensions now in use throughout the building. These are secured to woodwork and walls by means of staples etc. This practice constitutes a very serious fire hazard and we would request that all added cord be immediately removed and that wall receptacles be installed for use of added equipment, where necessary.

FIXTURES and CORDS.

Fixtures throughout building require to be overhauled. Where defective wire or sockets are found these should be replaced with standard material.
Cord drops containing joints should be replaced with new cord.
All sockets to be supplied with socket bushings where cord enters socket cap.
Remove cord drops which are within reach of bathtubs and control same outlets with wall switches.

Indian Agent,
Chapleau, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I shall greatly appreciate any help you can give me in trying to get the following improvements made at this school.

(1) I have for several years tried to get some action in matter of improved Recreation space for our boys and girls. Both sides of the building need more room. Perhaps now that there will be spare Gymnasia outfits left over from the war work athletic places the Department may be in a position to supply us with both space and Outfits for our Girls and Boys.

(2) Manual Training. This also has been brought before the Department at several times. I would like to institute this and are ready to do so if they will provide space and Equipment.

(3) I had a garage put here to store my car. This was done at my own expense. I am leaving the work this year. I would be glad to dispose of this garage for the benefit of the man who succeeds me in this work. The price I would ask for the garage is $95.00. I trust the Department will be able to refund this to me.

Perhaps I might state my resignation is due to age. I am due for Pension, and consider it my duty to make room for a younger man to take over the work.

(4) Repairs are urgently needed to put the Stannions in the barn in good shape. I would like to see this done as soon as possible. The cattle now get out almost at will. We have had to use Hay Wire to make temporary repairs.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Thelan:

Our Ass't Secretary-Treasurer, Mr. J.C.H. Forward, visited this school on April 16th and his report caused considerable unrest in the minds of members of our Commission. Mr. Forward specially commented on the run-down state of the building, the poor condition of the dining tables and benches and the rough cement floors in the dining room, kitchen and store rooms. He also reported that new stoves were required and the kitchen was very much in need of painting and being equipped with cupboards.

I can fully confirm these criticisms and have reported the conditions on several occasions. This particular school building appears to have been neglected for some years and is now one of the poorest of all that we administer. I am not forgetting that a considerable outlay was incurred by your branch in constructing a new chimney after a fire had demonstrated that the previous structure in the centre of the building was unsafe. I am sure, however, that it is not your desire that the building should run-down to the point when it will require very costly repairs to bring it up to standard.

I am asked to request that an official inspection of this building should be carried out and that necessary improvements should be effected as soon as I am able to get them in hand. May I specially stress again the condition of the cement floors. It is of dark and rough cement, exceedingly hard on the feet of our women workers and never looks clean however often it is washed. I hope that consideration may be given to providing some more suitable flooring especially for the kitchen and dining room. We expect to have a full staff of male workers during the summer with a new Principal, Engineer and Farm Instructor taking over in the fall and shall do our utmost to co-operate in carrying out any improvements that are decided upon.

Commending this matter to your usual kind consideration,

I remain,

Re: File 65-1-5, letter July 10th. 1946

In reply to your letter as above regarding the condition of the Chapleau Indian Residential School, also the letter attached from the M.S.C.C.

When I took over this agency six years ago the school was certainly in a run down condition, it was impossible to try to rectify everything at once, but a number of major improvements have been made.

The first was the installation of a new water main to the school the cost of which was well over one thousand dollars, over a period of five years all the old beds were replaced at a cost of about $1,750.00, after the fire in 1944 about $1,000 was spent in repairs and improvements, a new chimney was built at a cost of $1,286.00 and last year the electric wiring was all brought up to standard at a cost of $650.00, a little of this remains to be done as soon as the materials are available.

This was apart from all the minor repairs made and paint etc. supplied to keep the rest of the building in fair shape until the whole scheme was completed.

At the present time the most important job to be done is the roof, I have recommended for several years that this be done with a new roof covering over the main building with the proviso that it be left until the war was over due to shortage of men and material; I really think that this part of the program should be carried through this year.

When Mr. Arneil was here last week, we made a very thorough inspection of all the floors of the basement of the above school and agreed that the following repairs and alterations should be made:

1st. The floors of the girl's recreation room and the bakery should have hardwood floors laid over a subfloor and galvanized iron should be flashed around the walls of the bakery to prevent mice getting in.

2nd. The boy's recreation room and the dairy should be covered with a good layer of cement to a minimum of 2½ inches, later to be painted. The drinking fountain in the boy's recreation room should be moved into the section containing the wash basins. Re: File 65-1-5(WT-1) letter Nov. 16th/46.

This will acknowledge receipt of the above letter regarding the Chapleau School and the recommendations made by the Rt. Rev. William L. Wright, D.D., Bishop of Algoma.

I accompanied the Bishop when he went through the school, which is being reorganized at the present time under a new principal. One of the things pointed out by the staff was the very awkward layout in the upstairs clothing storage rooms.

There are two narrow rooms with a very high ceiling and the shelves for storage start about five feet from the floor, and it is necessary for the staff to use a stepladder almost continually when putting away or getting out clean clothing for the children. It was suggested that if the shelves on the floor were started from the floor and built up, and on the other side a piece of pipe hung underneath the present shelving so that clothing could be hung on hangers, it would be much easier to handle the clothing. This applies to both the boys and the girls storage cloak rooms.

With regard to the beds, the staff are using the same springs and mattresses as were got for the children, and although they are strong enough for a child, they are not strong enough to make a comfortable bed for an adult. I think that the beds themselves are all right but would agree that better quality springs and mattresses are needed for the staff. I would recommend that, if it is possible, twelve 3'3" size and two 4'6" size slat springs and spring filled mattresses to match the above springs be purchased.

Welfare & Training

We did not get all the buildings completed on the Constance Lake Reserve that we had anticipated. Eight were finished and are now occupied. Six others are all finished outside and the majority of the inside work done, and it will not take long to complete these when we start operations next summer.

The new roof was completed on the Chapleau School in the early part of the quarter, and a new stove is here and will be installed in the next week or so. Alterations were made in the storage rooms. In general I would say that the atmosphere around the school and the morale of the children is considerably improved under the new principal. In connection with this school I think the next thing that ought to be done is the replacement of the tables and benches used in the dining room. As reported before, they have been in use since the school was opened and, as the tops are of wood covered with a cheap linoleum during the course of time due to the linoleum breaking or the edges opening, a certain amount of water has seeped underneath, which creates both an offensive odor and a breeding place for worms under the cover. The condition of these tables was noted by Mr. Arneil last year, and while I am fully aware that a considerable amount of money has been spent this year and the available funds are apt to be getting low, I would still recommend that a serious effort be made either to secure enough tables, etc., from discarded military equipment or enough money be provided to have them built locally.

Application has been made for an educational trapping license in the name of the principal of the school, so that the older boys can be taught how to trap and properly dress the pelts. The township of Chapleau has been reserved for this purpose.

On the Constance Lake Reserve, near the school, the underbrush and most of the trees have been removed to eliminate fire hazard to the school and other buildings.

F. Matters,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 5th, 1947.

In applying you might state the cost per table so that if funds are not available for all that are needed, we could authorize some of them.

Bernard F. Neary

Apart from the loss of tools and damage to the wiring there was not much damage; we will have to build another door and frame to replace the one that was burnt, and replace the electrical equipment that was damaged or destroyed.

This fire in the furnace room brings up a matter that was discussed some considerable time ago, namely the danger of having the fire pump in the building where it could be rendered useless by a power breakdown; when the new water main was installed in 1941 provision was made by leaving a shut off valve outside the school so that the pump could be moved outside, and another small building erected to house it, and I think that it would be advisable to have this done as soon as possible.

When I arrived with the local fire brigade I found that the school staff had everything well in hand, the children outside in good order and all the staff quite calm and doing anything that could be done to contain the fire, and I would say that this saved the whole building.

Please advise if you desire to have the accounts for repairs to the wiring etc., put through during the present fiscal year or held until 1947-48, I would also recommend that the doors leading from the furnace room be fireproofed by being covered with galvanised iron.

F. Matters
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I have to report that we had a small fire in the Chapleau Residential School yesterday afternoon about 4 p.m.

The fire occurred in the furnace room in the basement of the school, destroying a cupboard which contained a quantity of tools, the door leading up to the passage way between the kitchen and laundry, and some of the electric wiring.

The fire was first noticed by the engineer who immediately got some of the fire hose with which the school is equipped working, whilst the children were being led out of the building by the members of the staff, by the time the local fire brigade got down the fire was almost out and it was only necessary for them to use some of their portable equipment to ensure that the fire was dead between the walls.

It would appear that the fire was due to some electrical defect, as the motor for the pump was burnt out, one fuse box was entirely destroyed and another one damaged, as the wiring had been very recently brought up to standard and examined by the Hydro inspector. I thought it advisable to have him come up as soon as possible to investigate and if possible find the reason for future protection, I called him by long distance at Sault Ste. Marie but he is not able to come here until some time in April, however I am holding the motor, along with the damaged fuse boxes and other equipment for his inspection.

In the meantime I have authorized the only available electrician, from Collins Stores Ltd., to make what repairs are necessary to get light and power going again.
Ottawa, March 7th, 1947.

Mr. F. Matters, Indian Agent,
Chapleau, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 5th inst., with reference to the small fire at the Chapleau Residential School. We are pleased to know that there were no serious results. It is expected, of course, that you will keep the cost as low as possible.

You may also arrange to have the doors leading from the furnace room fire proofed by being covered by galvanised iron.

Please submit the account for the repairs to the wiring. If we have funds available we will pay it this month. If not, it will have to be held until next month.

Dear Col. Neary: Re: St. John's Indian School, Chapleau,

I have just returned from a visit to the above school and desire at once to express my strong feeling in regard to the state of the building. I have on several occasions reported in similar terms to the Branch and understand that your Inspector and Agent have made many suggestions along similar lines. My discouragement arises from the fact that practically nothing appears to have been done in the past two or three years to make this building fit for the purpose for which it is being used.

In few words, this school is at the present time a disgrace both to the Government that owns it and our Church, which has been made responsible for the administration. It would seem that very little has been spent for years to maintain the building and it is in need of repair, plastering and painting from end to end. The whole basement area, in which the working quarters of the school are located, is almost beyond description. The floors are of a rough and dark cement which cannot appear clean, no matter how often they are scrubbed. In the children's dining room the floor has been broken up to allow access to the main below and unsightly holes have been left. The so-called boys' play-room floor has been so badly broken that it is really beyond description. The dining room has been given new tables recently which have come from some army camp and are not ideal but are a tremendous advance on the terrible tables formerly used. The benches, however, are beyond repair and the same condition prevails in the sewing room where the tables and benches are altogether unfit for use.

The Agent tells me that his repeated requests have been refused and that only a small item has been placed in the appropriation for the current year which will probably provide
floor covering for the basement rooms. My final impression is that this building ought not to be used until very considerable changes have been effected. I tremble to think of the effect that would be produced upon the members of the present Parliamentary Committee if they should visit this school in its present state and do not feel that we should be left in the position of taking the blame for what is really not our responsibility.

Our Principal is prepared to do what is possible during the summer months with the limited help available to brighten up parts of the building with paint if this is supplied, but I feel that when a school is so badly run down it calls for nothing less than a complete renewal, and this is altogether beyond our capacity.

I shall be grateful if you will look into this question and I am confident that you will find on your files plenty of evidence in support of what is written above. I can say without hesitation that this building is now in worse condition than any other administered by our Church.

Thanking you for your consideration, I remain

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

During our recent inspection trip to Chapleau we visited the Residential School and made an inspection of the motor work installed by Charles W. Colline Stores Ltd., this work being the replacement or equipment damaged in the fire. The electrician explained to us the condition of the conduit after the fire and we are of the opinion that this damage would be caused through the equipment being surrounded by fire rather than the cause of the fire. We arrived at this conclusion due to the fact that the parts of the conduit were found to be in a melted condition. This condition is quite often found to exist when wire in conduit is subjected to sufficient heat to destroy the insulation on the wire at which time an arc is drawn between the copper wire and the grounded metal conduit. In a case of grounding of the wires directly to the conduit the fuses protecting the circuit would open.

In this pump room there is at present a three H.P., 110 volt single phase motor, temporarily installed as understood, pending the arrival of the original motor. This motor is operated by a pressure switch; the fuses in the main switch of this device have been removed and the motor is, therefore, protected only by the main 60 amp fuses.

In order to supply adequate protection for this motor we would suggest that an enclosed type switch be provided for starting the motor, the existing pressure switch being used only for the operation of this magnetic switch. The motor should be reconnected to 220 volts instead of 110 volts.

Re: Chapleau Residential School.

The accommodation for married members of the staff of the above school is entirely inadequate and the situation at the present time is such that Mr. McNeil, Farming instructor, and Mr. Youngman, the engineer have reached the stage that unless better provision is made they will have to leave the school. Mr. McNeil and his wife and child is living in an apartment in the attic of the school, which in the summer is terribly hot, the temperature in the apartment last night at nine o'clock being 92 degrees, and in the winter it is unsafe, with no fire escape available.

Mr. Youngman and his wife are occupying space in the school which is needed for other members of the staff. He appears to be a very efficient engineer, something which has been required at this school for a long time, and they cannot continue to occupy their present quarters much longer.

Both these men have expressed their willingness to sacrifice their own spare time and holidays to assist in building other accommodation. They propose building either one large log house or two small ones. A rough plan of the small house is enclosed, and I think this latter would be preferable. They are prepared to get the logs and build the walls themselves, if we will provide materials and help to finish off the inside.

This matter is so urgent for the efficient operation of the school that I would strongly urge that every assistance be given them immediately. On going over, roughly, the materials required, I think that the two houses could be made habitable for the sum of $1,200.00 and I would strongly recommend that we carry out this plan.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Refrigeration, Chapleau School

This morning in your office we discussed refrigeration and I mentioned that, as a result of a recent farm report indicating that milk had spoiled, I had written for a report on the refrigeration facilities there. The place in question was Chapleau and when I returned to my office I found the undermentioned report, dated 1st October, from the Principal of that school.

"During August when we had only a few children, there was more milk than we could use and we arranged for the local dairy to take one milking a day. However the remainder was frequently spoiled before the next meal due to no facilities for proper cooling and no refrigeration.

"This matter has been under discussion with the Dept. and the local Agent over the past two years but so far there has been no action in the matter. Inspector Arnell was here during the summer and when I took him to see our refrigeration plant, his only comment was "disgusting." And it was, but that is what we have had to use to keep our food and milk. It consisted of two old ice boxes that were in such poor condition that the water from the melting ice ran down into the milk and food and then through onto the floor of the dairy. That was bad enough but the we packed sufficient ice last winter to last us the summer, the old ice house is in such bad condition that half of it melted and before the end of August we had no ice left.

"In one day not long ago I had to throw out some 50 lbs. of meat and all the morning's milk as it had all spoiled. The agent here has repeatedly asked for all these things."

I am sure you will agree that, under conditions as described, the preservation of foodstuffs that require
refrigeration becomes difficult if not impossible. We would be very glad, therefore, of any action you can take to remedy the situation.

Obviously, a new installation is required and I suggest for consideration a large or "walk-in" type in which a reasonably large quantity of meat could be stored so that we could take advantage of purchase by the quarter, side or carcass.

At your convenience, will you please advise what you will be able to do in this connection.

Yours truly,

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Chapleau Indian Residential School.

At Noon on Mar. 2nd a fire was reported at the above school and I went down immediately with the Chapleau Fire Brigade.

On arrival we found that it had been extinguished by the school staff. The outbreak consisted of a fire on the outside of the building just above the stone foundation. The floor inside was quite hot and the walls were warm. Part of the cement trim and some stucco had been pulled off to get at the seat of the fire, and, to insure that there was no fire in the walls and between the floors, a small area in the ceiling of the basement storeroom was pulled off.

There are no electric wires, stove pipes or chimneys at the location of the fire, and, after a careful examination by the chief of the local Fire Brigade and myself, we arrived at the conclusion that it had been caused by a spark from the laundry chimney dropping down into a very narrow crack, where the cement had been forced away from the building by the action of frost.

As the wall was broken through, and to prevent any danger of frozen pipes, I had a carpenter go down at once to make the necessary repairs. The total amount of damage would be between $25.00 and $50.00. There appeared to be no doubt that the fire was purely accidental, and the school staff did well to kill it before it had the opportunity to spread.

F. Matters,
Superintendent,
Chapleau Indian Agency.

Dear Colonel Neary:

This office letter of 3rd October, 1947, to you submitting services for inclusion in your 1948-49 Estimates in respect of the above-mentioned school contained a lengthy extract from the Principal's report on the fire hazards and lack of fire escapes there.

I now have received a letter dated 2nd March from the Principal which reads as follows:

"When we arrived back from the station we found everything in excitement as the building was on fire from the chimney. It was not anything serious from a damage point of view but as it is the second time we have had a fire start in less than a year, I wish to again emphasize the fire hazard that we have here and refer to the report I put in last October; briefly, that in case of a fire getting a head start during the night, half of the occupants of the building, both staff and children, would be trapped some 50 feet from the ground without any means of escape. This is the third time a fire has started from reasons beyond our control, which is a most disturbing situation for those who live in the building especially.

"We can be again most thankful that the present fire occurred during the daytime and was quickly extinguished. The conduct of all was splendid and the action of Mr. McNeill and the boys in bringing the fire fighting equipment into action received high commendation from the town fire department."

Will you please advise me of what action is being taken to reduce the fire hazards to which the Indian children and staff at this school are exposed as described in this office letter of 3rd October, 1947, and in the foregoing quotation.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent

The Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Chapleau School

The barn at the above school has not been used for cattle for some little time as all the cattle have been disposed of, and milk is purchased locally for all the school needs.

I have proposed that the building be made into a recreation room or gymnasium on the upper floor, and ground floor used for manual training.

This would mean the stripping of the bars etc., for the cattle from the ground floor and the levelling of the concrete troughs, in connection with the former I have an offer of $75.00 for the stables and manure carrier, this material is all very old and really has only salvage value and I would recommend that it be accepted.

Due to the very little dairy farming in this part of the country the possibilities of sale are very few and the material would have to carry heavy shipping charges if shipped elsewhere.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter as above with the copy of the letter attached from the Superintendent of the M.S.C.C.

I was out to the school yesterday again to examine the matter of the fire escape; I found that the fire escape on the girls' side of the building in good order and the door leading to it unlocked, but on the boys' side the door to the fire escape was locked, this escape leads from the junior boys dormitory; the senior boys are on the front of the building and have to pass the top of the stairway which would be the danger point in case of fire, but their room door is locked also at night which means they would have to both doors opened before even reaching the fire escape.

Extra fire escapes on the front of the building would be an asset and provide the maximum of safety for the children and staff but they would be useless unless this idea of locking doors at night is discarded, but the staff appear to be reluctant to do this.

The question boils down to a matter of funds available, the most pressing need at the present time is for some provision of refrigeration, and quotations are being asked for to provide a walk-in refrigerator, if money is available for both jobs then I would recommend that they be done, but if a choice has to be made I think the refrigerator should be first, and that the present fire escapes properly locked after and made available for instant use would suffice for the time being.

May 1st, 1948.

Mr. F. Matters, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Chapleau, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 24th ultimo, file 76-2-34 (65), with reference to the Chapleau Residential School. In view of the information contained in your letter, we do not consider it necessary to erect a new fire escape at the present time. If you consider it advisable you may have the door cut through the wall as mentioned in the last paragraph of your letter.

However, you should point out to the principal of the school that at frequent intervals in the past years, the Department has insisted that doors leading to the fire escapes be kept unlocked. We must insist that this procedure be also adopted at the Chapleau School. If the principal refuses to carry out our instructions, you should advise us at once so that we can take up the matter with the head office of the M.S.C.C.

If you consider it necessary you may purchase and install panic bolts on the doors leading to the fire escapes.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Chapleau Indian Residential School

This is to inform you that the above named school is now closed and the keys to the building are in my possession. Rev. Crawley has packed and shipped all materials belonging to the Church to several schools throughout the Dominion.

At present there is one room in the school which contains desks and some school supplies which are to be used in the new Mountbatten Day School when it is completed. This room also contains bedding and other welfare goods which will be distributed among the Indians of this agency as the need arises. The above material is being stored there as there is no storage space to be had in Chapleau.

Memorandum:

The Director,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: File 462-5
Letter September 9th, 1949,
Chapleau Indian Residential School

On receipt of the above letter I arranged to make a quick trip to Chapleau. I knew that Mr. Whitney was away at the Mattagami reserve but as I am expecting to leave for the western part of the region on Sept. 20th, I could not delay. Mr. Watt of The V.L.A., who has his headquarters here had received a similar letter. Inasmuch as he had been present when the initial appraisal was made we decided to go together.

We found that the letter from Mr. Gionet was entirely contrary to the facts. All plumbing fixtures, sinks, toilets etc. were exactly as they were when the appraisal was made. None of them had been removed since the school closed. We found that four electric receptacle boxes, wall type, had been removed at some time. Mr. Watt advised me that they had been missing at the time of the appraisal. There were very few electric light fixtures in use when the building was occupied. These still remained, the balance of the lighting was from plain drop cords.

The only door missing was the screen door from the front of the building. This is in use at the cottage occupied by the watchman. There are several more windows broken which can be attributed to normal wear and tear. In almost every case of a broken window we found the carcasses or one or more birds on the floor. Undoubtedly they were the cause of the damage.

I suppose that Mr. Gionet is anxious to have the deal closed as quickly as possible. He did not mention the one thing that is causing and will soon be responsible for more damage to the fabric of the building. The roof is leaking in a couple of places and water has dripped through the ceilings to the basement.
There was no evidence of any material having been removed. I would say that the watchman has done a good job. All doors except the front are nailed securely. Some water was coming into the basement from the water main. I showed him where it could be shut off before it reached the school.

Personally I am of the opinion that quoting the upset price in the advertisement militated against a larger number of bids. People thought that this was the minimum that would be acceptable. For tender of Mr. Gionet is the only one received I would suggest that it be readvertised omitting the upset price, and that the highest tender received be accepted without delay.

The location of the property tends to reduce its value. It is costing $40 per month to protect it against pilfering, therefore should be disposed of as quickly as possible. The watchman complained about the amount he was receiving. I had to agree that it is very meagre considering that he has to be around the place at all times and cannot do any other work. When the school was in operation he received most of his meals there. His salary should be increased by about $15.00 per month to ensure proper protection for the buildings until they are disposed of.

(sgd) P. Matters

Chapleau Residential School.

The above noted letter was in the mail when I returned from my trip to Mattagami Reserve yesterday. In view of the contents of the attached letter from Mr. Nicholas Gionet, an immediate inspection of the school was made by myself.

The information concerning vandalism contained in paragraphs 2 and 3 of Mr. Gionet's letter, are entirely false. With regard to electrical fixtures; several sets of electrical plugs had been removed from this building by unauthorized persons during August 1948, before the watchman was employed. Since that time no electrical fixtures have been removed from the building. All switches, plugs, ceiling fixtures, drop cords etc., are still in place and could be put into immediate use, by reconnecting the service with the powerline.

Regarding the plumbing fixtures; the only plumbing fixtures which have been removed from the building were the sinks and washing machines, dryer etc. from the school laundry, which were removed by Rev. Cramley before the school closed and were shipped to an Indian Residential School out west. At present in the building, there are 5 complete bathroom outfits in good working order, six separate bath tubs, 20 wash basins, 6 utility sinks and 6 toilets. All of this equipment could be put into immediate use by turning on the water in the building. I would like to point out here, that at my request, the caretaker Mr. Kinney, bailed out and drained all these plumbing fixtures in the fall of 1948.
to insure that there would be no water left in the traps that might freeze and split any of the equipment.

Regarding the windows at the school. I would venture to say that 50 panes of glass of various sizes would complete repairs on all the windows in this building. Most of the windows cracked or broken were in this condition when the school was closed. I would say that there have been less than a dozen panes of glass broken in this building, during the past year. This in itself is remarkable, as the school is more than a mile from town and the surroundings are convenient play spots for children of this locality.

Concerning the outside walls of the building. These walls are in essentially the same condition today, as they were at the time of the closing of the school. There are quite a few cracks in the outside stucco coat and in two or three places some pieces of this stucco have fallen away completely.

I might say that no one from Chapleau or anywhere else that I know of, have been to Mr. Kinney with the story that they had authority to remove anything from the building, and since Mr. Kinney took over, I can find no trace of any fixtures, plumbing, glass doors etc. having been removed. The only gates, formerly used from the school, were taken in August 1948 before Mr. Kinney took over as watchman. In fact it was because of this, along with removal of a few electric plugs, that this office requested a caretaker.

I feel that having had a caretaker in this building for the past year, has not been a waste of money. There is no change in the condition of this building or its contents, since it was valued this summer.

My Dear Lad Bishop,

I have your favor of the 15th inst. with the enclosed communication from Mr. D.C. Scott, Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs. As to his objections to the removal of the Indian Boarding School from this center to mine, what we intended was not a total locality. I fully appreciate the interest he has taken in the matter and believe that the School has done all he hopes it could do, and results have fully justified its establishment. But when a new building is to be erected, and considerable expenses incurred not only to the Department but also to the Church, it appears to me a desirable matter to consider some more suitable locality in which to build. I shall try and give you my views as briefly as possible.

In the first place perhaps Mr. Scott has not kept pace exactly with modern Railway development. At the time the Chapleau Boarding School was erected neither of the two Railways to the north of us were in course of construction. Now both the Canadian Northern and the Grand Trunk Pacific run through the very centre of the country in which the Indians, from the families of which we draw our supply of children. I do not know that we have not asked in the last fifteen or sixteen years for a new building near along the line of the C.P.R., where we stand now the Chapleau Boarding School. But although quite a few times we have been told by the Indians they very rarely reside on their own land. However, opposite the town of Chapleau, but not too far from the river around where the C.T.R. and the G.T.P. have been built, this country remains as there, and it is there they tell me they plant their families in the most part. A school located there would meet their every wish as they have practically wished for such a move on our part.

Secondly, the land is practically all cleared up on the school lot, and it will be simply impossible for us to buy by the acre. There is neither sufficient land for Agriculture nor even for pasturage, nor will there be occupation in a time of peace, all the year round until at least three years are needed to make an improvement, and when improved the prices are such that it would almost cripple us to pay them. Dear Bishop Anderson -

I have your letter of the 5th instant, in reference to the plans for the new Boarding School building at Chapleau. By making some interior alterations, which will not depreciate the utility of the building nor increase its size, provision can be made for sixty pupils and our architect is now having these changes made. The building is to be steam heated. I am aware that the heating is a heavy item of expenses and it is for this reason that I could not consider it advisable to increase the size. I am sure, however, that the plan will be satisfactory.

A very important matter has been brought to my attention within the past few days, namely, the site. I understood that if we were to remain in Chapleau the present site or its vicinity was the only one available, but just the other day I learned from outside sources that a more suitable property could be had adjoining the river, just across the C.P.R. bridge on the west side. This site is situated about one mile from the town of Chapleau on the East side of the river, and has a frontage thereon extending the full length of the two lots. The land is considerably diversified, but generally free from stone, and will, after clearing a considerable portion, make valuable farm land suitable for all agricultural purposes, particularly hay and root crops. Other portions are higher land, and possess all of the requirements for a good school site, admitting of excellent drainage facilities, and an abundance of water can be had, either from the river or in sinking a well near the school.

The site to a great extent is free from rock, and while the soil is light and of a sandy nature, and may prove unproductive for agricultural purposes in places, the poor land can be utilized as wood lots for fuel purposes.

This site is within a very short distance of the Electric Light Company's power line, and there is no doubt but satisfactory arrangements can be entered into with this Company for the necessary energy required for the lighting of the buildings and operating their machinery.

In connection with this site it will be necessary to build about one mile of roadway, connecting with road leading to the present building, near the bridge recently erected by the Department for crossing the river there. The estimated cost of this road will be about $300.00.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that the Department is acquiring lots number 1 and 2, concession 4, and 1 and 2, concession 5, township of Chapleau, for Boarding School purposes, and as tenders will be advertised for in a few days, it will be necessary to have a road made through the property to the site chosen for the school.

The road should be such that materials can be taken in readily as well as the supplies for the school and located in such position that it can be maintained and permanently improved for the school and adjoining reserve.

The Department is of the opinion that you should employ as far as possible Indians on the reserve for this work, their wages to be according to the amount of work done, rather than a fixed sum per day, and all of the work to be under your immediate oversight. You should appoint a reliable and experienced foreman to take charge and report to you during your absence.

Department will send you an accountable cheque from which you will make the necessary payments to the workmen, and for which receipts in duplicate must be taken. The work should be commenced as soon as possible so that it may be well under way if not completed before the middle of August.

Your obedient servant,
